Agents should see that full explanations are given by the teacher in the column for "Remarks," if the school was closed during the quarter for other than authorized holidays, and should also themselves make any necessary comments in that column.

INSTRUCTIONS TO TEACHERS

1. Fill up all the columns in this Return.
2. All the columns of the Return must be added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.
3. Number and date of holidays to be inserted in the column for remarks.
4. By the total number of school days in the quarter is meant the number of days in the quarter exclusive of Saturdays and Sundays. All authorized holidays will be allowed.
5. The standing of each pupil must be signified by inserting opposite his or her name the figure 1 in the column designating the particular grade.
6. No names other than those of Indian children are to be included in this return.
7. The quarterly Returns must end on the 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December respectively, and be immediately thereafter in each case transmitted to the local Indian Agent.
8. When, owing to the number of pupils, the form of Return is not long enough to contain all the names, use another form, paging it as No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns. Do not increase the length of the form by pasting another, or portion of one, to it.
9. The average daily attendance during the quarter may be ascertained by dividing the total number of days' attendance of all the pupils by the number of days school was open in the quarter.
10. Should the school be closed at any time during the quarter, the reason must be given in the column for remarks for such day or days.
11. The school must be opened and closed punctually at the hours approved of by the Department.
12. This form to be used for Day Schools only.

Name of Instructor: John G. Somerville.

It should be fully understood that this is an Indian Day School with limited room and equipment, and the work is therefore governed by these facts. The work however, is planned so that the pupils will gain a full knowledge of construction and wood-working joints that will be useful to them in after life.

The classes are held for one day of each week and although this is a one day school, the amount of work accomplished compares favorably with that in any school carrying it in periods for a whole week. Besides wood construction; sheet metal and metal are co-related with the projects and in some cases plan drawing is also taught.

Before appending the number of pupils and the work they have been engaged in, taken from the register, from April 1, 1933, to March 31, 1934 it might be advisable to state that a great deal of repair work is also being done. During the last two months the following are some of the articles which have been repaired: spinners; tubs; lamps; table; chair; bicycle; drag-saw; gun; and axes and hammers shafted etc. In addition to this, the pupils are encouraged to bring any tools which they may have at home and put them in working order.
Examination of the files, when this school was started, it is noted that the instructor was asked to find room and equipment for ten boys. The register now shows an enrollment of over twenty pupils; the morning session as much as possible being given over to the seniors, and the afternoon to the juniors. The school, especially for the last two months, has been a little over crowded, the February attendance percentage showing 98%. The attendances in Winter and Spring however, are generally much higher than the Summer and Autumn.

General Remarks

(i) I am quite sure the pupils are interested; and the projects are laid out so that their interest will be held. The Instructor has found that there is an innate love amongst the Indian boys, to work with wood-working tools.

(ii) The trend today is for more and more practical education in our schools; and, judging from results and observances of the boys taught this particular branch of training; I would say that the money spent is more than justified. If anything, this training should be extended; results cannot be measured by dollars and cents.

(iii) In the first place, let me say that the Instructor would welcome constructive criticism from any competent inspector, and is quite willing to stand aside at any time if the boys can be better helped. Mr. John Kyle, Organizer of Technical Education for B.C., has visited this school once or twice and has had nothing but praise for the work being done and its practical nature. The tragedy of youth today is that after school training, no positions are available. I should like to suggest that some of these lads be given an opportunity to further develop an outlet for the practical training which they have received.

As has been suggested by the Department, the boys might make caskets. This could be done, not only for our own Reserve, but for the whole Island extending up from Duncan. This project could be tried out at no expense to the Department, excepting the cost of material. If specifications were available, we could estimate the amount of costs etc.

Secondly, so many of the Indians are fishermen and live at the seaside that a course in boat building (small boats) would fill an urgent need. Again here, as above, it would be a matter of first cost.
There is an old shed here that is available and that would be suitable for such work.

If these two courses could be worked out and started, the writer is confident that the school would soon pay its own costs, which on the whole, are very low.

J.G. Somerville
Instructor

Dear Sir:

Having reference to your letter of February 28th asking for a report from Mr. J.G. Sommerville, Manual Training Instructor at Nanaimo Indian Day School. I now have much pleasure in enclosing Mr. Sommerville's report which is very comprehensive, and I do not think that he overestimates the work that these pupils are doing.

We have had examples of the work that can be done by ex-pupils in the building of the houses that have been recently built on this reserve. The boys are taught very practically and it is really hard to improve very much upon the work that is being done, with the exception that perhaps if the department supplied material that coffins could be made and kept in stock it would save the department on various occasions when these have to be purchased. The classes are so well attended that the building is often found to be a little too small.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the vacant position of Manual Training Instructor in the Nanaimo Indian Day School, I may say that when last in Nanaimo on inspection duties I had a short conference with Mr. Indian Agent Graham and Mr. J.G. Sommerville in the hope that we could find a suitable candidate. I asked Mr. Sommerville whether he considered an Indian would be able to undertake the duties with any hope of success. It will be remembered that Mr. Sommerville has been the Provincial Manual Training Instructor for the Nanaimo Schools for many years and has also been in charge of the work in the Indian Day School. Mr. Sommerville promised to consider the matter and said he would later suggest a candidate for the vacant position. He rather favoured the employment of one of the Indians.

Edison Whyte, an Indian of the Nanaimo Band, is now applying for the position of Manual Training Instructor at the Indian Day School. While I do not remember this boy passing through the Day School, I am very glad to know that Mr. Sommerville can recommend his employment. I notice that Mr. Indian Agent Graham suggests that Edison Whyte be employed in a temporary way till the end of the present school year on June 30th 1936. I would recommend that Edison Whyte be appointed Manual Training Instructor at the Nanaimo Indian Day School, the appointment to be a temporary one till I have an opportunity to inspect the work done by his class. There is a new teacher at the Nanaimo Indian Day School this term and I shall make a point of visiting the school before the end of June, possibly just before Easter. At that time help will be given to Edison Whyte should the Department make the appointment recommended above, and his work reported on in the usual manner.

In forwarding this recommendation may I draw your attention to paragraph 2 of Departmental letter 155-11-11 dated December 7, 1937.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Your voucher No. 119 was issued in favour of Inkster & Thompson Lumber Company, Nanaimo, and requested payment of $5.00 for lumber for the manual training room at the Nanaimo Indian Day School.

The second item on the account read: "90 ft. B.M. clear spruce at .50¢ and the extension read $5.40. The correct extension is $4.50. This means that the total of the account should have been $5.00 instead of $5.90. A cheque for the former amount is being forwarded to the company.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

J. D. Caldwell, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Duncan, B. C.
The small boys are making good progress in the making of toys and small articles. A few of the older boys have made satisfactory articles. The class has not been operating to allow me to judge in any sort of final way whether the Department is justified in continuing this work, under the guidance of an Indian.

I would recommend that the Manual Training Shop be put into good repair, a heater supplied as mentioned above, the necessary new tools purchased, and the experiment continued for the school year 1938-39. Edison Whyte in my opinion might well be informed that he has to show during the next School Year that the expenditure of the Department's funds on his salary and the Manual Training Shop in general is worth while. The Indians are at present trying to get as much for themselves out of the Department as possible and it is obvious that those boys not attending the Day School should be excluded.

I believe that it would be well to retain the services of this young Indian as instructor for another year but that he be informed that his salary will only be paid monthly and that if considered necessary the arrangement may be terminated at any time with a month's notice.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B. C.
present pupils of the school are given instruction in very elementary Manual Training. The older school pupils, the four mentioned above are in the afternoon employed on school repair work etc. Some of the ex pupils have been coming in the afternoon also but I have asked that this be not allowed as all the time and space is required by the small boys.

At the six single benches and the long bench for three pupils only about nine or ten pupils can be properly accommodated. It is necessary to exclude the ex pupils of the Day School in the afternoon, as the little people require great attention in learning to work with sharp tools if we are to avoid accidents.

A register has been kept in a rough exercise book since April. From this I have been able to extract the following information:

Total Morning Attendance 21 for 6 lessons
Average attendance in Morning Class 3.5

Total afternoon attendance 63 for 6 lessons
Average attendance in afternoon class 10.5

At first the ex pupils gave trouble and had to be warned by the acting Indian agent. The worst of these older boys have left.

I do not consider that the Department should permit those Indians who are not attending the Nanaimo Indian Day School to receive Manual Training instruction here. The three or four older boys with perhaps a few more from the lower Grades later will make a Morning Class.

The whole of the work done should remain the property of the school and not the pupil. It should be exhibited and sold and at least half of the money so obtained should be retained for purchase of materials and other articles for the school and particularly the Manual Training Class. Most of the articles made should be for the definite use of the school however. A number of small articles are required now by the teacher. The boys must be instructed that though they make articles from school lumber, with school tools, and in school time, these articles will not in future become their personal property as in the past.
A Singer sewing machine is badly needed by the girls to enable them to learn to make their own clothes. Such machines are used in the Indian homes, and the older girls need this training. I would recommend that such a sewing machine as is used in the Residential Schools be supplied to this Day School.

I wish to strongly recommend the granting of the sum of $100.00 to the school for the purpose of starting the above mentioned native wool work. This would cover cost of material and salary of Indian woman for the coming school year. After this the school might be able to carry on the work on the money obtained from the sale of articles.

As reported in December 1937 the old school now used as a Manual Training Shop is some 20 feet by 30 feet. There are four windows, one of which needs repair and all need wire mesh screens to protect from damage by balls. A new door which will lock is urgently needed. The outside walls of the room in one place at least need renewal.

As mentioned in my previous report a new coal burning heater is required if this room is to be used.

A fairly large number of tools are urgently needed if any worthwhile Manual Training is to be carried on here. It must be possible to lock the Manual Training Shop door, and there should be a locked cupboard for the new tools and the few now in the room. The list of what is required will be prepared by the present teacher of this subject and sent to the Acting Indian Agent at Duncan.

Sir,-

With reference to your instructions of October 15th, to make an inspection of Kamloops, B.C. Agency, I have to report as follows,-

x x x x

Schools.

It would appear to me that a day school at the head of Okanagan Lake would be a great boon to these people. A settlement is fast surrounding them. Two bright young girls about thirteen years of age, appeared before Dr. McDougal and myself and asked that they might be assisted to learn to read and write like the white people. The band desires the school which I think should be a public school and would strongly recommend a school being established in this district.

x x x x

Your obedient servant,

Sgd. J.G. Ramsden,
Inspector.
Re Schools

Rosy Dupret and Josie Chaco.

There are about fifty children eligible for school.

Q. By Ins. Ramsden would you girls like a school to go to.
Ans. Yes, to learn reading and writing.

Q. Do they think lots of the other children would like to learn like to read and write by the white people?
Ans. Yes.
Re Education— I found in the Kamloops and Okanagan Agency two boarding or industrial schools, one at Kamloops and the other at or near Lytton, these being full to their utmost capacity, yet falling far short of the needs of the people. The Indians themselves brought this matter to me and repeatedly importuned for schools. "Day schools, on or near the Reserve" "Secular Day Schools" these were what they asked for, and after going over the Districts I would recommend that day schools with competent teachers be established at Enderby and at the head of the Okanagan Lake, and also in the Lower Similkameen country, also at Bonaparte near Ashcroft, and also at Spencer's Bridge, further down the Thompson. This would give this District five day schools, which in my judgment, are very much needed and for which, as above stated, the Indians have most earnestly asked for.

(Signed) John Macdonald.
Ottawa, February 7th, 1910.

Sir,

The establishment of schools for the Indians of the Lower Similkameen, Bonaparte and Okanagan reserves has been recommended and the Department is disposed to favourably consider the requests of these Indians.

There are several matters in connection with these propositions on which the Department desires full information. The first is the site in each case. Is there a suitable site available within reach of the majority of the Indians, affording drainage facilities and suitable soil for gardening purposes, if desired, and a good water supply? If a school is to be erected, what style of building would you recommend; what material should be used in construction; how many children should be provided for and how ought it to be heated? You should also give an approximate cost of material and labour, and give your opinion as to the best means of construction, whether by contract or day labour.

You will recollect that at Enderby it was decided to utilize the council building for a time; but the Department is not aware of any buildings at the localities now under consideration that might provide temporary accommodation. If there are such you will be good enough to so state.

The Department will expect you to give this matter your immediate attention, so that operations may

Okanagan.

The great majority of these Indians live on the N.E.I. reserve, which surrounds the head arm of Okanagan Lake. The principal village is situated at the head of this arm and is always referred to as Head-of-the-Lake. Within and tributary to this village there could be collected a school population of 15 children, and possibly some might come for a greater distance for a portion of the time.

There is no building suitable for school purposes. The water supply is distant and not good in summer. A garden plot might be secured, though a crop would be uncertain near the village. But I might say that half-a-mile distant from the village there is a good spring creek, and this would be the most suitable spot for school and garden.

The school building could best be constructed of lumber, and heated by a stove. By contract would be the most satisfactory means of construction, as I would not look for these Indians to unite on any undertaking. I estimate a building would cost $700.00.

Indians were the most opposed and the freest in expressing
their opposition, and the younger men who favour the school
have not the courage to oppose old reactionaries like Komasket. Another thing that affected the vote on the last occasion was the proximity of the time for re-election of the Chief. Pierre Michel is really in favour of the school, but he is afraid of the opposition and refrained from voting on that account. Had there been no election in sight he would doubtless have voted in favour of the school, and others who held back as well, would have been sure to follow his example.

I think it would have been better if the last vote had been deferred. The prospects for the return of Pierre Michel as Chief do not appear to be very bright, but it is possible that Pierre may decide to drop out of the running and throw his weight in with Jimmy Joseph who was his best Councilman, and there is a possibility that Jimmy Joseph might carry it. He appears to be the best man in sight, and if he should be successful it would be an opportune time to revive the school propaganda. Until the Chiefship is disposed of it would seem to be better to allow the school to remain in abeyance.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 27th ultimo in regard to schools in Okanagan Agency.

In reply I beg to say that the situation in this Agency with regard to Indian education has always been deplorable. The only Indian school in the Agency is in Osoyoos band at Inkameep village, and the building in which it is being conducted is the merest excuse in the way of accommodation, while the teacher is living in a tent on the bank of Inkameep Creek, summer and winter.

Attempt has been made at various times to induce the Indians of Spallumcheen, Okanagan and Penticton bands to establish schools at suitable points on their reserves, and votes to that end were taken by the former Indian Agent, J. R. Brown, but in every case the Indians voted it down. At one time previous to my connection with the Department the Spallumcheen Indians did think of having a day school opened on Spallumcheen reserve No. 2 at Enderby and school furniture was procured, but for some reason the school was never opened and the furniture was shipped to Penticton for the Osoyoos school and hauled by Osoyoos Indians to Inkameep. Nothing was ever done about a building for the school at Enderby, and it is perhaps fortunate, in a measure, that no special building was erected for the purpose, in view of the possibility that Spallumcheen reserve No. 2 may be given up for a soldiers' settlement and the Indians
Indians moved over to reserve No. 1 on Salmon River. In that event the new church at Enderby would be moved over to Salmon River and the new church at Salmon River would serve admirably as a school building.

In regard to the Okanagan band an enumeration has shown that there are over 50 Indian children of school age on the Head of the Lake reserve, but unfortunately from the configuration of the reserve it would be impossible for one school to accommodate them, as they are scattered along a shore line of about 22 miles at the Head of the lake and down the east and west sides. To accommodate all these there should be a school at either Siwash Creek or Six Mile Creek, which could serve for Whiteman's Creek, Siwash Creek, Six Mile Creek and Blacktown. Then there should be a school for those at the Head of the lake which children from the east side could attend, although some of them would have to go 5 or 6 miles. The Council House at the Head of the Lake might be used for a school, but a building would have to be provided at Siwash Creek at a cost of about $500.00 or thereabout.

At Penticton an Indian school could easily be maintained and no building would have to be provided, for the Council house could be used. The older Indians are opposed to a school and most of the younger men and women are indifferent. Unfortunately, too, most of the clergy of the Roman Catholic Church which is the only church concerned in Indian mission work in this Agency, are opposed to Indian day schools. With one exception, Father John, who was in charge at Penticton in 1917, none of them have given encouragement to the establishment of a day school on the Penticton reserve; and had he remained there a year longer, I believe we could have had one started. There may be something in their contention that Indian children require the discipline that is more easily attainable in the industrial school or boarding school, but where institutions of that
that kind are not always available where there are Indian children to educate, it seems unreasonable to maintain this opposition to the day school which in so many cases is the only means within reach, and Indian parents want their children at home with them while they are being educated in day schools, as well as white parents.

A difficulty often connected with the day school is to find living accommodations for the teacher where the services of white teachers will have to be depended upon, and there will be some difficulty of that kind in a school at Siwash Creek where there is no white habitation near enough in which a white teacher could board; but no difficulty of that kind would be experienced either for the Spallumcheen Indians at Enderby or for the reserve at Penticton. In this connection also it is desirable where possible, but not essential, that the teacher should have knowledge of the Indian language, and it is singular that the boarding schools for Indian girls in some of the other Agencies do not seem to turn out Indian girl teachers.

After all the main thing requisite in all these Indian communities where reactionary tendencies on the part of the older members of the band, sets them against schools of any kind, is a firm hand for compulsory education. It is a mistake to allow a group of reactionary Indians in any band to dominate the situation and deprive Indian children of the education they should have. Also, if the church is to be entrusted with Indian education, it is desirable that its educational policy be sufficiently elastic to embrace day schools where industrial or boarding schools are clearly unattainable. There are instances where Indian day schools are doing excellent work in Agencies where there are industrial schools as well.
The Indian day school at Boothroyd in the Lytton Agency is a notable example, and the interest taken by Indian parents in the education of their children in that case, is most marked. Compulsory education was necessary at one time among the whites and is still provided for by statute, although it is now rarely necessary to employ it. From the attitude maintained by these bands in the Okanagan Agency towards education of their children, there should be no hesitation about putting in force compulsory education in Indian communities like Enderby, Head of the Lake and Penticton, where there appears to be no other way of obtaining education for these children.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to bring to the Department's attention the matter of building a day school on the Okanagan Reserve No. 1. There is only one school in this Agency at present, it being on the Inkhameep Reserve at Osoyoos where there are only seven pupils attending.

On the Okanagan Reserve there are over 50 children of school age who could attend a school at a central point, and having looked the situation over very carefully, I find that 6-Mile creek would be the best location although another school will be necessary at the Head-of-the-Lake later on.

The cost of the school and teacher's house would not exceed $3000 as the lumber is easily obtained at present on account of a saw-mill being in operation on the Reserve. The difficulty of finding a suitable place for a teacher to live would be overcome as there are white people living near this locality at 6-Mile creek. Memo for File:

Indian Education Vote 1921-22 provided for the Okanagan Indian Day School, but the building was never erected. Indian Education Vote 1922-23 provided for Salmon River and Penticton Indian Day Schools - neither of these schools will be built, but the money voted for the Salmon River School is being used for the Okanagan School. These last mentioned day schools are situated close together and have been confused on the files - thus the indecision regarding building.

The File Numbers are: Okanagan 164-5, Penticton 164-10, Salmon River 552462.
The Okanagan school building is well under way, the concrete work being completed. One of the Indians, Gasto Louie, went to the school site when building operations were commenced and attempted to prevent work going on. I thought it best to attend to him right away and went over there at once and gave him distinctly to understand that any interference with the building would be severely dealt with. I have had no complaints since from the contractors. The Mounted Police also saw him after his attempt and I think in future his opposition to the school will take the form of letters to the Department. I understand that he has a coterie who have been signing a petition about this school, but other Indians have come in recently and said that they are satisfied to see it on the Reserve and have taken their names off the petition. The instigator of this is Jimmie Antoine, an Indian who was educated at the Kamloops Industrial School and apparently wishes to deprive every other Indian of the same advantage. He is opposing the school whereas he was one of the appointees to the Allied Tribes Association meeting at Vancouver, although, I believe, he got lost in North Vancouver and did not attend the meeting with the Minister of the Interior. I cannot quite follow this man's reasoning as I believe the Allied Tribes were asking for better educational facilities for Indians so apparently he is trying to curry favour with both ends on the Reserve with a view to being elected chief whenever such an election is held.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, regarding the obtaining of a teacher for the Okanagan Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say we note that the Rev. Father Welch objects to the employing of the teacher from the Lytton Industrial School, and, also, that the teacher nominated by him is not satisfactory. We further note that you are endeavouring to secure the services of Mr. and Mrs. Marsden, who are at present teacher and field matron, respectively, at the Homalco Indian Day School in the Vancouver Agency.

In this connection, I beg to confirm our night lettergram to you of yesterday's date:

"If Mr. and Mrs. Marsden transferred from present positions to Okanagan school the services of former only will be paid for at rate of $850 per annum. Field matron not required and salary cannot therefore be paid Mrs. Marsden".

I may say that Mr. Marsden is in receipt of salary at the rate of $800 per annum as teacher of the Homalco school, while his wife is paid at the rate of $40.00 per month for her services as field matron. Besides this, they have both received bonus as provided by law. We have had no intimation that it is their intention to give up duties at this school, and, as stated in our night lettergram, if they are transferred to the Okanagan school, we would only require the services of Mr. Marsden. It would be necessary, before a field matron could be appointed, to have the position created by the Civil Service Commission. We do not intend to appoint a field matron at Okanagan and, therefore, you will observe, if both the above named are transferred to take charge of the Okanagan school, that it would be at a considerable pecuniary loss to them. We consider that it would be advisable for them to remain in their present positions. However, it is noted that you expect them to arrive during the present week, and if so, we would approve of the appointment of Mr. Marsden as teacher, but we do not require the services of his wife as field matron, and cannot allow her salary.

I may say, further, that we do not pay travelling expenses of teachers and cannot, therefore, arrange to pay any part of the expenses of the above named from their present school to the Okanagan school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A meeting of the Okanagan Band was held on the 30th at their request. This is the most difficult Band in the agency to handle, and the one I have tried to do most for. They have every advantage possible, the best land, most irrigation, ample grazing and timber lands, and fishing; in fact the Okanagan Reserve No. 1 is in my opinion the ideal reserve, yet the Indians on it are the most dissatisfied and quarrelsome Band in the Agency. If they would not listen to a few low-down white people who are always ribbing them up, they would be further ahead. They are continually getting up petitions and round robins keeping all the members unsettled who do want to work and make something of their lives. At the last meeting they were protesting about having a school at all as "Indians don't need education." At this meeting they were led by Jimmie Antoine in protest against the location of the school. Of course there are a number of good, sound hard-working Indians who strongly disapprove of all this agitation by Jimmie Antoine and his clique but their voices are seldom heard at the meetings. One old man, Komasket, who lives on the best farm in the Reserve said after the meeting, "We know Antoine, you know Antoine, that's enough. The peculiar thing about him is that he attended school at Kamloops but opposes others attending. I understand a petition will shortly be forwarded about the school and am told the writer is R. Gillespie, of Vernon, who rented the Antoine Estate, but is in default with rental and is a continual source of annoyance to this office.

Mr. and Mrs. Marsden arrived on the 26th. Mr. Marsden is teacher at the new school on Okanagan Reserve. They appear to be capable people and I feel sure the school will be in good hands. Owing to an oversight in the plans, no provision was made for heating the residential quarters and a furnace had to be provided before they could occupy same. While our Okanagan climate is mildly advertised, we still require heating in the houses during the short cold snaps when the temperature drops ten to fifteen below zero.

Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith four day school reports from this Agency; one of them, the Westbank School, being for four Indians attending at Westbank Ferry Public School.

These reports show fifty children now receiving an education and there are twenty-two others scattered around the various public and residential schools who do not show on any of these reports. I hope it will be possible in the near future to have schools available for all the Indian children in this Agency. Those who are attending show a remarkable keenness and one of the teachers informs me that the children arrive as early as 7.30 in the morning and, if allowed, are sometimes in the school room after nine at night, and made a request that they do not close the school for Easter holidays. The teachers also report that they are having no trouble with discipline, the elder children keeping the younger ones in order voluntarily. Some of the work done in the short time two of the schools have been open is remarkably good.

There is opposition to the schools on the Reserves among the older Indians, but this seems to be lessening weekly. On the other hand many of the parents have come to the office specially to express their gratification to the Department for starting the schools.

Penticton and Okanagan Bay Schools were visited during this month, where progress is being maintained. The discipline is good in both schools and the children very keen.

It is much regretted that there is still opposition to the schools among certain of the Bands, these being the trouble-makers referred to above. They have the effrontery to tell the Bands that they have been supported in this opposition by the authorities at Ottawa! As an example of the way they try to mislead the more ignorant Indians, two of them sent a letter to His Excellency the Governor General. The reply they received was merely an acknowledgment by the Governor General's Secretary, but was read to them as "appointin Baptistie Chief, and boss of all the Indian lands" (Baptiste being one of the trouble-makers). Of course the majority pay little attention to the agitators and these Indians are seldom heard from, but the minority make a great deal of unpleasantness and noise out of all proportion to their numbers. However, the idle season is over and they will now settle down to work for another season and will not have so much spare time on their hands to employ in stirring up discontent.

I beg to place before you the following circumstances with reference to the school on Okanagan Indian Reserve No.1. This Reserve is a narrow one, but is seventeen miles long, so that it was impossible to place the school where it would be within walking distance of all the children on the Reserve, consequently some of them have been unable to attend. Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of another of your uncalled for and extraordinary letters dated the 14th inst.

I suppose it gives you some sort of satisfaction to have these defamatory epistles - questioning my ability of running the school - on file. Had you taken your own advice "talebearing be not accepted as proof of guilt" - to wit, - and had you had the courtesy to come to the school and investigate for yourself, before giving expression to the statements your letter contains, you would have found:

First - There had been no child dismissed from the school.
Second - No one has been unjustly accused.
Third - No one is punished through talebearing nor is talebearing tolerated.
Fourth - This boy Ned Louis, whom you state is not fifteen years of age, was entered in the school register on February 1st, 1923 as eleven years of age - said age being supplied to me by his own parent when he was brought to school on that date. Ned Louis is now over sixteen years of age.

Ned Louis was never dismissed from this school, but when in class, he was insolent and insubordinate. I warned him, that he would have to leave the school if he did not behave himself better and he was too over age. He thereupon walked out of the school in the middle of the class, feeling quite sure of the support of his parents for his action. However, he returned the next day, and I punished him by keeping him in his schoolroom during recess to write an imposition. Since then, the mother has kept both her boys away from the school.

The accusations:- None have been made, but owing to Ned Louis' immoral conduct in front of the school windows, so public - no investigation was at all necessary. I, as teacher, with the welfare of the school children at heart, presume I have the right to keep such a boy off the playground without being subject to any officious interference.

I may say, on our return from our leave of absence, we have had some anxious weeks with the children, as their conduct has become so loose. In this connection, two mothers visited us, immediately on our return, saying they were going to take their girls away from the school, had we not returned when we did.

The parents of Ned Louis also called and complained to us, that practically all the parents of the children at the school, had visited their house, complaining of the conduct of their boy, Ned Louis, towards their children.

Had you been so solicitous about the attendance of Mrs. Pierre Louis' children at the school, as you would wish...
your letter to infer,— why did you not ask Mrs. Louis for her reasons for keeping her two boys from school—Ned Louis 63 days, Walter Louis 75 days during the six months prior to our return. You have the figures in your office.

Knowing, as you do, the antagonism of Ned Louis' mother and several others, towards schools, and the mischief they are capable of making, it would certainly assist matters, if you could bring yourself to show a little loyalty towards the teacher, when they come to you with their mischievous tale-bearing, instead of taking the ground from under his feet and encouraging insubordination among the children, and unhappiness in the parents, by listening to their imaginary grievances, thereby taking all authority over the children out of the teacher's hands, as you have done on previous occasions.

I should have thought, you would have seen, all the time this woman Mrs. Louis was talking, she was simply seeking an excuse to use her boys at home, as the record of their attendance should have shown you.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

"William Macdonald"

Dear Mr. Marsden,

I have received several complaints recently that some of the school children have been accused of wrong-doing without any proof being produced and these accusations have created a hostility to the school among those parents who intended sending their children as soon as a bus was supplied. Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith copies of two letters, one written by me to the teacher of Okanagan Indian Day School and the other his reply.

My letter was written in all friendliness and I was astounded to receive such an epistle from him. He apparently made several carbon copies of his letter so Mr. Cairns, School Inspector for B.C., received one. Mr. Macdonald is a sick man and physically is not fit to be teaching, but his wife, who is doubtless well known to the Department, assists him and incidentally causes practically all the unpleasantness possible in connection with the school.

I have left the Macdonalds severely alone in their conduct of the school and absolutely do not know what he means by accusing me of "officialness and interference". I know it is their opinion that the Agent has absolutely nothing to do with the school except to attend to their numerous requests, which are unceasing. I have always done everything possible for them (which they do not appreciate and consider it is due to do) by arranging transportation for them when they come to Vernon, taking them out to the school at considerable personal inconvenience, attending to their mail and carefully forwarding it, also telegrams and cables have been delivered to them at most inconvenient times and in fact every courtesy and help has been extended to them. Personally I consider Mrs. Macdonald a great detriment to the school and a confirmed trouble maker and I sincerely hope they will find another school more suitable to their peculiarities.

With regard to the enclosed letter Mrs. Pierre Louis seems to have incurred their displeasure. As a matter of fact, Mrs. Pierre Louis had nothing to do with the complaint, it was Pierre Louis who came to my office and said he was seriously considering removing his children from the school on account of Mr. Macdonald's action towards them. Pierre Louis is far and away the best Indian in this Agency, he is absolutely truthful, honest and industrious and it was through his efforts, in spite of bitter opposition from other Indians, that the school was made possible and it is only his loyal support of education which loses him the Chiefship, the majority of the voters being opposed to the school. The complaints Pierre Louis made to me were quite rational and made without rancour or heat and were entirely regarding Mrs. Macdonald's treatment of his son, he said Mr. Macdonald allows his wife to do as she pleases with the school and I know from personal observation that this is true and it is a serious drawback as she is totally unfitted to have charge of the pupils on account of her temperament.

No one questions Mr. Macdonald's authority over the pupils and if it were not for his wife there would be no
I now wish to call particular attention to paragraph six of the letter. This may seem much or little, but in any event it is absolute nonsense to say that the conduct of the children became loose because Harsten's were absent for some months last year. During their absence Mr. Frank Grist was employed as teacher and if Mr. Harsten is making any reflection upon his character I beg to advise that such reflections are lying, slanderous and unwarrantable. Mr. Grist is a gentleman in whom I have entire confidence; his integrity and uprightness are without question and I was extremely fortunate in obtaining his services. Mr. Grist is a Roman Catholic and it was not easy to find a teacher of that religion at short notice to fill in during Mr. Harsten's enforced absence and it is pitiful to see such statements as this in Harsten's letter. I notice two others visited them on their return saying that they were going to take their girls away etc. May I mention that many parents told me they hoped the Harstens would not return so their children were doing so much better in school and in proof of their confidence in Mr. Grist I may also add that he formed a night class for the parents who he was teaching to read and write. This I think entirely refutes any statement that the conduct of the children suffered during Mr. Harsten's absence. However, I quite expected to hear some such thing as this from Mrs. Harsten's remarks even before they had reached the school on their return and I consider Mr. Harsten should be severely censured for making any such statement without more proof than his wife's surmises.

I have visited this school as seldom as possible and have never interfered in the slightest with Mr. Harsten. They are kindhearted people and I like Mr. Harsten very much, but he is completely dominated by his wife who is a most unpleasant, foolish and interfering woman and I wish to respectfully, but strongly, protest against receiving such a letter from this teacher.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th inst. in connection with the resignation of Mr. Quigley as teacher of the Okanagan Indian Day School. I visited the school yesterday and found it still closed and from an examination of the living quarters have come to the conclusion that although Mr. Quigley applied for three days leave and later wrote from Vancouver asking for three days extra, he had no intention of returning. The quarters were dirty and the furniture had been carelessly handled and the place looked quite dilapidated.

In case Mr. Quigley ever applies for another position it may be well to report that I have had trouble with him almost from the day of his appointment. He tried to undermine the priest who attends the Reserve, the Agent and everybody who had any dealings with him. I had numerous inquiries about him from all sorts of people, a warrant for him was sent to the local provincial police in connection with non-maintenance of his family, and recently there was an advertisement in the Vancouver papers asking for information as to his whereabouts. He was also in trouble with his nearest white neighbour on the Reserve on a timber deal and he was undoubtedly encouraging the Indians to cut timber from their allotments for sale through him, although his name did not appear. However, I checked this as soon as it came to my notice.

I did not wish to trouble the Department with his many activities, which have caused me considerable unpleasantness, but I was seriously considering placing the facts before you at the end of this term. He has been on the quota for entry into the United States and apparently his turn has now come and personally I consider we are well rid of him. Your instructions as to a successor are being followed and I hope to send an application for your approval in the near future.

Sir:

I enclose herewith a letter addressed to you received from the Secretary of the Indian Crafts Guild on Okanagan Indian Reserve No.1. Under separate cover I am forwarding at their request a sample of their work for your use.

In explanation, I would advise that the Guild at present is composed of pupils of the Okanagan Indian Day School under instruction of Mr. Anthony Walsh. Mr. Walsh attended the B.C. University Summer School during the vacation, specializing in handicrafts, and has made considerable headway with this work among his pupils during the Fall term, and the children are very keen indeed on the work, a few of them displaying outstanding talent. The small basket is one of their early attempts with rattan, and it well conveys an impression of what they are doing. I loaned the School a simple weaving loom and four frame loom with which they are turning out good work, considering their short experience. I have also recently loaned them a pyrographic outfit, and they are experimenting with burnt leather and birch bark decoration. They have already turned out a variety of articles decorated in various ways and at present, in addition to their ordinary school work, are engaged in making up birch bark greeting cards, and other novelties to fill orders from white people. Already they have added over $20.00 to their school library fund, which represents a small contribution from each article sold, and the library is growing fast. The most recent request from the Guild is for an autographed copy of Dr. Scott's poems.

It might be interesting to know that the Guild, which is also a Junior Red Cross "branch" conduct their business in a perfectly formal and business-like fashion with regular meetings where questions are gravely debated and subject to resolutions, and this without the "interference" of the teacher.

One of the great hopes I have for this handicraft training is that in the event of these children ever being stricken with T.B. or other disability, they will be enabled to support themselves and considerably improve their chances of getting on their feet again, as probably the greatest difficulty in securing satisfactory results with tubercular Indians is due to the fact that they will not rest for any length of time.

You are probably aware that this school secured...
first place at the recent Indian Exhibit at Kamloops and great credit is due Mr. Walsh for his keen interest in this, as well as his agricultural instruction during the summer months.

OKANAGAN AGENCY.
MONTHLY REPORT FOR MONTH OF DECEMBER 1930.

The schools concluded the fall term very satisfactorily. The Okanagan school is an outstanding success in every way, and the pupils are confronted with a bigger demand for their handicrafts than they can fill. A number of these pupils have provided themselves with winter clothing from this source and the teacher, Mr. Walsh, believes several of them will be self-supporting in a few years. This, of course, in addition to their routine studies. The attendance at this school is increasing and it is not at all unlikely that new desks, etc., will have to be provided in the comparatively near future, as a number of children living at a distance from the school are now anxious to attend. The Osoyoos children are contemplating the formation of a Boy Scout troop, and it is hoped that this can be brought about. This school, under the care of Mr. Grist, is very successful, his strong point being agriculture and stock, and his work in the reserve is equally as valuable with the adults as with the children. Penticton school has a much harder problem on account of the opposition and indifference of the Indians.

James Coleman.

Much greater interest is being shown in this school lately. During the inspection of this school, a short conference was held with the Indian Agent, the Teacher, the Missionary, Rev. Father Sullivan, and the Indian Chief Pierre. 6. SCHOOLS: I regret that at the moment I cannot find my notes upon the Day School on Okanagan Reserve No. I. I must, therefore, rely upon memory. The teacher at this school has a system of allotting gardens to the various children, and though early in the season, I found the gardens all planted and the children taking a great interest in each individual garden. Recommended for the position of teacher of the North Okanagan Indian Day School:

Miss Marie Hepworth, Box 284 Trail, B.C.

Miss Hepworth is a Roman Catholic, age 21, trained at Victoria Normal School (1921-22), holds a B.C. First Class Interim Certificate, and has about four months experience as a substitute teacher in Grades 2 and 3 at the Trail Central School. She is about five feet three inches tall and weighs one hundred three pounds. She has taught Sunday School for some eight years, and is very well able to teach the children their Religion. She has been always in the best of health, and when not in school has worked in a drug store gaining a knowledge of simple drugs. She is prepared to dispense the usual medicines to the Indians. Miss Hepworth gets on well with the children placed in her care, and to qualify for a teaching position in one of our Indian Schools, gave up a position to attend the courses in Primary Work and Indian & Rural Problems at this year's Provincial Summer School here. In fact I have had Miss Hepworth as a student in my class for the past five weeks, and have observed her attitude and class work with some care. She can play the piano or organ and is well able to conduct a choir. She is also quite good at cooking and sewing, which subjects she is prepared to teach to the girls.

Miss Hepworth's aunt a lady of some fifty years of age is prepared to make her home with this teacher at the school, as otherwise I could not recommend a single girl being given this appointment. I may add that this nomination has the express written approval of His Grace the Archbishop of Vancouver, Archbishop Duke. I wish also to strongly recommend Miss Hepworth's appointment, and would ask that a copy of this letter be forwarded with your recommendation when the position becomes vacant.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Okanagan Indian Agency,
Vernon, B.C.,
September 21, 1937.

Sir—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant with reference to the appointment of Miss Catherine McDonald to Okanagan Indian Day School and my comments in my monthly report for August in reference to the appointment of a woman teacher to this school.

As I had not met Miss McDonald at the time of writing the report the statements therein did not in any way refer to Miss McDonald personally but entirely to the type of teacher I considered desirable for this particular school. I fully appreciated the circumstances in regard to her appointment and on her arrival immediately endeavoured to assist her in every possible way. As it was apparent that she was unfamiliar with handling Indian children and general educational procedure, I had Mr. F.G.M. Grist, recently of Seabird Island School and now in Vernon, endeavour to assist and advise her in detail, this man having been eminently successful when teaching in this Agency and having taught at this particular school at one time, with success. There was no expense to the Department in this connection. As it was evident that Miss McDonald was still somewhat off the line I deemed it advisable to bring Miss M.E. Weydert up from the Penticton Day School to give her a day. Miss Weydert being the most competent and successful teacher we have ever had in our work and being a woman I thought possibly she might make a more effective contact with her in some ways than Mr. Grist. I think between the two of them and myself we have possibly acquainted Miss McDonald with our requirements and methods.

So far as I can see Miss McDonald is a very fine type of woman typical of the teacher of a small Ontario school of twenty-five years ago and the whole problem is that of adapting her to the type of education now in vogue and many of the young teachers are finding difficulty in meeting the recent changes in curriculum in British Columbia. If this can be done I have no doubt but that she will do excellent work for this Department and you can rest assured that she will be given the fullest and most sympathetic cooperation from myself and my staff in every way possible. This school would be a problem even for an experienced Indian teacher as I consider it is in a somewhat run-down condition and the children have lost interest in the work, consequently it would not be fair to pass an opinion on Miss McDonald's work until she has been with the children for some months.

I am not entirely satisfied with our educational set-up as regards its value in training our Indian children for the work they will undertake on their maturity, both for boys and girls, and feel that we are merely tending to make them dissatisfied with their future prospects, which in this Agency hold out a great deal more promise for them than

R.A.Hoey, Esq.,

REPORT ON OKANAGAN AGENCY FOR MONTH OF DECEMBER 1937.

SCHOOLS

It is uncertain at present just how the new teacher will succeed with the Okanagan Day school, but there is no doubt of her industry.

James Coleman,
Indian Agent.
Schools

These have been making their usual progress. Miss Weydert of the Penticton School is marrying a young Catholic school teacher, who has very excellent reports from his inspectors. Miss Weydert has proven unusually successful with this school and as her husband made application to join our teaching staff after his marriage in July, I thought that it would be an excellent idea to have this young couple take over the Okanagan Indian Day school, which has always been a problem, there being a number of adult girls attending and the attendance has fallen off rather badly in recent years. It has an enrolment of 35 pupils with the last average attendance being only 24.68. It was considered that this young couple working together on the problem could promote the interest of the children and that a young married woman could handle the elder girls by securing their confidence and bringing them to a better understanding of their responsibilities, as well as handle the domestic science end of the teaching, the young man being quite capable of taking the boys with elements of agriculture and manual arts. However, to my surprise the present incumbents, two aged ladies, are not taking favourably to a transfer to Penticton where I felt they would be much more comfortable living in the town and free from the inconveniences of living on a reserve where they are liable in ordinary winters to be snow bound for weeks at a time, besides the undoubted advantage of taking over a school that has been brought up to an excellent standard, by Miss Weydert. Personally, I would prefer to see competent male teachers in all of the three day schools in this agency in order to give effective training to the boys on agricultural subjects as well as the orthodox curriculum and have part of the available time allotted to training these youngsters in what will eventually be their life work.

James Coleman,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the vacancy for a teacher at the Okanagan Indian Day School, I enclose herewith nomination by His Grace E.Q. Jennings, Auxiliary Bishop of Vancouver, of Gregory Schiller who, it will be noted, has no professional qualifications but is well recommended by the Bishop. It will also be noted that this applicant has been exempted from military service apparently on medical grounds.

It has been found quite difficult to secure teachers for these positions, and, while I am not favourable to the appointment of unqualified persons, in view of the Bishop's recommendation I would approve of Mr. Schiller being engaged on a purely temporary basis until such time as a qualified teacher can be secured.

This school has been conducted on the basis of a term of 9 months at a salary of $100 a month, and reference to your files will show that the $100 a month rate was paid to Mr. Curtis in consideration of his wife, who was formerly teacher at the Penticton Indian Day School, devoting a part of her time to teaching the children domestic science, etc. In view of the fact that Mr. Schiller is not qualified professionally and there are excellent furnished quarters built on to the school, I would recommend that he be paid a salary of $90 per month for the school term ending June 30th unless a qualified teacher could be secured before that date.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Bishop Jennings:

Considerable concern is being felt by the Department in that we have been unable to secure a teacher for the Okanagan Indian Day School which has been closed for some time.

Although Section 10, subsection 2, of the Indian Act might appear to imply the right of the church in this connection my own view is that the reference was intended to cover the operation of residential schools only.
This case should serve to focus attention on the imperative need for clarification of the position of the church in the matter of the operation and control of the Indian Day Schools in this province. There should be no place in this country for a policy that makes education to our Indians, which under the law is the sole responsibility of the state, dependent on decision of church authority.

MEMORANDUM

TO D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner
FROM R. F. Davey, District Inspector of Indian Schools.

Re: Appointment of teachers to Indian Day Schools.

There are at present eleven Indian Day Schools in B.C. closed because of the present shortage of teachers and it is likely that the majority will remain so unless those teachers available are used.

The Okanagan Indian Day School is an example. This school has been closed since June 1945. Recently there has been two possible appointments, one, a young woman of eighteen years of age without teaching training, and the other, a qualified man with nineteen years experience. To send a young woman of this age with virtually no experience to the isolated Okanagan school is unjustifiable. This is particularly true when a mature qualified man is available. Apparently the only obstacle in the way of opening this school is obtaining the nomination of this teacher from the church authorities concerned. This nomination was apparently refused on the basis of the teacher's religious convictions. This is one example where an appointment to a school has been prevented because it has not been possible to secure the nomination of the teacher by the church authorities. There is no need or excuse for a teacher's religious convictions interfering with his work in a school or his work in the church and community.

The attendance at Provincial Normal Schools indicates that the present shortage of trained teachers will not be overcome for two or three years. In view of this I suggest that consideration be given to a change in the present policy of appointing teachers to Indian Day Schools only after a nomination to the position has been secured from the church authorities concerned.

R. F. Davey.

Sir,

OKANAGAN COMBINED DAY SCHOOL AND TEACHER'S RESIDENCE.

I beg to report that the building of the above school is proceeding very satisfactorily and the shingling was completed yesterday. The specifications have been faithfully carried out by Mr. Moffat as far as they have gone, the only change requested being in the finish of the walls from a plaster of Paris to a sand finish as authorized in your telegram received today which reads:

"May substitute sand finish for Plaster of Paris".

It is expected that the extra time requested for painting the outside of the building will not be required now, as the outside painting can probably be done within the next few days, the weather being still above freezing point in the Valley.

I notice that the whole construction of the building is more substantial than usually seen in this part of Canada, and has been favourably commented upon. If it is not presumptuous for one not an architect to make a suggestion for future schools, I would like to draw attention to the windows in the class room. It appears to me that if they were raised about 12" or 2 feet they would allow better light on the opposite side of the class room which on a dull day will be noticeable, and will also
prevent the children looking out of the windows during school hours. Of course this can be accomplished at a sacrifice of some light by painting the lower panes of glass, but in my opinion the better plan would be to raise the windows. Fortunately, the window side of the school is to the south, with no trees, etc., obstructing the light but similar favourable conditions might not always exist in other localities.

It is hoped that the plans for the Penticton School will not be unduly delayed as the temporary quarters are over-crowded already and not very convenient, the teacher there, Miss Coughlan, is complaining of the lack of space, and difficulty of satisfactorily heating a small crowded room like the priest's house.

I have heard nothing about the Penticton proposed School for some time and trust it will not be overlooked. I am reporting separately upon my visit there last week.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

I have the honour to report that the Okanagan combined day school and teacher's residence has been completed and I made a final inspection of the same today. The work has been done in a most satisfactory manner and no attempt made to change the specifications in any way although some of the dimensions, etc., were of a nature not often seen here. On two or three occasions I have taken with me Mr. R.B. Bell, the pioneer architect of Vernon who has done the Bank of Montreal work in this Valley for many years and has built most of the best houses in Vernon so his opinion can be relied upon. He told me today that the job is one of the best he has seen, and that the Department is to be congratulated on the building, which is much superior to the Provincial schools. I appreciated his courtesy, which was offered voluntarily on account of long standing friendship, and feel more assured in reporting the successful completion of building operations seeing that it has been expertly inspected.

No provision was made for bringing water to the building. There is a creek within 75 yards of the School and by going up stream 1,200 feet enough fall can be obtained to have water piped into the house and I have asked a local man to give me an estimate of labour and material to bury a pipe this distance to a depth of four feet. Upon receipt of this information I will forward full details for your consideration. Mr. Moffat, the contractor of this school is also fire-chief of Vernon, and he states that although there would not be high-pressure in such a pipe-line, it would be of some
assistance in case of fire. With reference to the usual fire-extinguishers placed in Government buildings, will these be supplied from Ottawa or shall I receive instructions to purchase them? The heater has been set up and has been kept going to thoroughly dry out everything before occupation and I have arranged with a trustworthy Indian, Pierre Louie, to see that a small fire is kept on for another week as in this damp weather there will be much "sweating" in the plastering.

Mr. Moffat advises me that the heater purchased as per your instructions, is perfectly safe and exactly the right type and size. As fire-chief, I consider his opinion can be accepted in such matters without question.

These particulars are respectfully submitted for your further instructions.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to bring to your attention the plans of the above school (which was duly completed last month). It was pointed out that no heating was provided for in the residential part of the building but we considered the school room heater would be sufficient. However, upon the arrival of Mr. Macdonald and his wife, who has accepted the position of teacher, they complain that such heating arrangement is wholly unsatisfactory, as any heat obtained from the school-room would be figure and totally inadequate. Upon reference to the plans it will be seen that the only chimney provided is in the rear of the building and connects to the kitchen range and the stove in the school-room. I went out to the school on the 27th to try and find some way out of the difficulty. At first I thought it would be possible to put up a small heater in the living-room and connect it with the kitchen chimney, but this is impossible on account of the low ceilings and lack of space. An alternative scheme would be to put a metal pipe from the living-room far up the flue above and carry it out through the roof but however well-protected it might be, the fire risk would still have to be considered.

The same objection prevented putting a pipe through the east wall of the living-room and carrying it up outside the building, bringing it with stoves from the oven. Another plan would be to build another chimney but this would be an expensive undertaking even if feasible. After reviewing all these circumstances and considering the urgency of getting heat into the living quarters, I have taken the responsibility of ordering a small furnace to be placed in the cellar under the west end of
the living room and a register cut through the floor close to the west wall; the furnace smoke pipe to be connected with the present chimney. This will be sufficient to heat the whole of the residential portion of the school, the school room being heated by the present arrangement of a wood stove which is satisfactory. The cost of this, including material and labour will be approximately $175.00. There is only one such furnace in town and it is quite a satisfactory and large enough one for the space to be heated.

I sent a short lettergram today as follows:

"Okanagan Day School plans do not provide heating in living quarters. If readers have arrived but do not live in the building without heating. I have ordered furnace and have forwarded full report in explanation of this action.

I hope this arrangement, which is the only practical one, will be acceptable to the Department and I would respectfully suggest that in any other plans for buildings of this size & at two chimneys be provided for, or if only one is built that it is placed where stove-pipes can be carried to it from all parts of the building. This appears to me to be a serious defect in the plans provided, which was not noticed before as the weather has been mild enough for the school heater to take care of the other rooms, but as previously stated heat obtained from a classroom would not be sanitary.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

re: Irrigation - Okanagan I.R.No.1.

With reference to enclosed vouchers for work performed in connection with irrigation on Okanagan I.R.No.1, I beg to advise that this was work of an emergency nature, affecting the Indian Day School, where a school garden had been planted by the children, and owing to the unusual dry weather, no time could be lost in supplying it with irrigation. This source of water will also furnish the teacher with domestic water during the summer, pending an investigation of a more permanent supply, as requested in your letter of April 21st, (file 164-5-5).

An old Indian above the school had also put in about an acre of garden truck, which was also threatened.

This ditch will bring the water on to a level where it will be available for other Indian families, but will require enlarging somewhat. The total cost of labour was $45.60 and in view of the fact that we are required by the Provincial Water Board to bring considerable additional acreage under irrigation from this source, I recommend that only a portion of the cost of this ditch be charged to the School, and have prepared one voucher for $9.90, the balance I would recommend be charged to the funds of the Band, as it is of direct and immediate benefit to the Indians themselves and being used by them.

It is possible that a small amount of flume at the intake may be necessary at a later date during the dry weather when the level of the creek drops, and this would make an additional cost of about $35.00, but the expense will be avoided if possible, as a main ditch at a much higher level and serving other and more distant land will be required to bring about 400 additional acres under irrigation, and this is being investigated, as soon as the Census is completed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

JODH.

(James Coleman)
Indian Agent.

Considering the very serious series of cases of illness in September, 1933, I wish to again draw the attention of the Department to the poor water supply at this school, and to my report on this subject after an inspection on March 20, 1931, and after an inspection on December 2, 1931. Ill health at this school is costing the Department considerable expenditure. Sir:

re: Your File No.164-5-5.

Replying to your letter of March 17th with reference to Mr. Inspector Barry's report of February 14th re periodical inspection of this school by a qualified nurse, I beg to advise that I have been making enquiries, but so far have been quite unable to find any means by which this service could be adequately performed by a nurse.

The school is situated seventeen miles from Vernon, the nearest town, and in winter is often inaccessible to car travel by reason of snow drifts. A combination such as we have at Osoyoos Reserve, where a Victorian Order Nurse visits the Reserve and school at least once a week and spends the rest of her time with the white population, would be a satisfactory arrangement, but there appears to be very little likelihood of anything being done along these lines in the neighbourhood as the area adjacent to the Reserve is too sparsely populated to support a nurse, except on the Vernon side, which, of course, is served by medical practitioners.

I have discussed the question with the Department's Medical Officer for this Reserve, Dr. E.G. Baldwin. This officer's work with the Okanagan Band has increased to such an extent during the past four years that he has found it necessary to take on a partner, Dr. Pettman. There has been a very marked increase in maternity work alone. A few years ago practically all such cases were handled on the Reserve by Indian midwives, but they are increasingly demanding medical attention. Also there is the increasing demand of the Department for special attention to such matters as trachoma, tuberculosis, communicable diseases, etc. Dr. Baldwin suggested that it might be found more economical to include the special care of the school in his official duties, and that for an increase of his remuneration to $100.00 per month, he would undertake at least two routine visits to the school with his own nurse each month, and any special work that may be found necessary. Dr. Pettman's association with him ensures continuity of the work.

There would be undoubted advantages in this arrangement, in that the children would not only have the attention of a nurse, but what, in my opinion, is much more important, the individual oversight of a competent practitioner. Such an arrangement last year when we had an outbreak of Bacillus Enteritidis among one family of school children would have avoided four deaths and extremely heavy hospital and medical accounts, which amounted to probably somewhere about $1,000.00. Dr. Baldwin's present salary is $66.60 less 10%, per month. I would venture the opinion that he and his partner are the most competent medical men in the agency.

The extension of Dr. Baldwin's work would cost an
additional $40.00 per month. To secure and operate with a nurse from Vernon in the ordinary way would involve a minimum return trip of 34 miles, and over to the extent of visitation of children's homes, so that on a basis of 10¢ per mile there would be a minimum cost of $3.40 per trip, and in addition the nurse's fees for the day. From a point of cost alone, it is questionable whether any saving would be effected.

I have been in communication with Mrs. E.A. Pease, who resides about 10 miles south of the southern extremity of the Reserve, and about 15 miles from the school, and I enclose a copy of her letter, which is not particularly helpful and the suggestion that she and another lady contribute to the cost of medical services for the Indians, I presume could hardly be considered, notwithstanding the philanthropic motive which actuates the offer.

Personally, I am rather inclined to the Medical Officer handling the proposition as suggested, particularly in view of the fact that his present remuneration is, in any event, not commensurate with the calls on his services.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 15th instant refusing payment of Voucher No.5590 in favour of Miss D.Heelas, clerk in this office, for transportation of Miss Hepworth to Okanagan Indian Day School to take over duties as teacher there.

In this connection, I would point out that this was not merely a courtesy extended to Miss Hepworth. I was absent at Vancouver in connection with the admission of Basil McLeod, alleged insane Indian of the Okanagan Band, to the Provincial Mental Hospital, and the fitting of an artificial arm for Tommy Christian, Indian of the Spellumcheen Band, when the new teacher arrived, and it was necessary for one of the staff to be at the school in order to turn over to the new teacher, the keys, records and supplies, and check things over generally, and as the school is seventeen miles from the railroad, it was naturally more convenient to take her along for this purpose.

Miss Heelas has from time to time done a considerable amount of running around for the Department in her private car when I have been absent from Vernon elsewhere in the Agency, and provision for this contingency has always been made in my Estimates, there being no Constable here who would in the ordinary way attend to such matters, and this is the first time payment has been requested for her.

Sir,-

A report received from Inspector Barry regarding his inspection of the Okanagan Indian Day School on the 21st ultimo reads, in part, as follows:-

"The hot air furnace in the basement should be connected to the schoolroom, where a new hot air register should be constructed. In building the school, provision has been made for this hot air pipe and an opening in one wall constructed. All that is required now is the necessary pipe, and register, and the work of installing these. The old heater in the schoolroom is not now satisfactory. It is smoking and needs a guard placed around it if it is to remain there. With extra desks when they are supplied, it will be in the way in its present position. There is a very long smoke pipe. In any case, this pipe should be cleaned out at once. I believe that there is much soot in it. If it takes fire, we may have an accident, as often these excessively long smoke pipes fall down when they are red hot. I certainly recommend the provision of the pipe from the existing basement furnace. This will save fuel as there will be no need for the heater in the schoolroom."

If you consider that the Inspector's suggestion is practicable, you should make the necessary arrangements for the work, as it will not likely involve any heavy expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

James Coleman, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vernon, B. C.

A. F. MacKenzie.
