Sir,

In Okanagan Indian Day School

I provided in my 1935-36 estimates for an expenditure of $400.00 to cover cost of painting the exterior of Okanagan Indian Day School, which has not been painted since it was erected in 1922.

At the time of making up the estimates I had not been able to make a very detailed examination of the structure but can now furnish a report covering its condition and considered it advisable to place this in your hands for reference when required.

EXTERIOR: The building is of frame construction, on cement foundation walls, shingle roof. The exterior surfaces are in a very dry condition, the paint worn off, leaving the surfaces exposed to the weather elements. Due to this condition a noticeable shrinkage has taken place on west wall. Shingles are in fair condition but need repainting soon as their preservation is to be maintained. Foundation walls are showing full of hair line cracks allowing the penetration of moisture which in a short time will weaken the strength of the walls and permit spalling.

Materials needed:

- Foundation walls - Concrete - 178 linear feet
- Average height of 2' 6" = 445 sq. ft., material needed for this surface, Cement Paint together with primer.
- 1 gal. of paint and 2 gals of primer, colour gray
- 1 gal. of paint @ $3.50 per gallon ----------------------$3.50
- 2 gals Primer @ $2.85 --------------------------------$5.70

- Walls - Siding - There is estimated to be 2350 sq. ft. surfaces on the four walls for which is recommended a coat application of suitable paint. Material necessary -
- 7 gals. suitable paint @ $3.00 ---------------$21.00
- 3 gals. suitable paint @ $3.10 ---------------$9.30

- Sufficient white paint estimated in above quantity for two coat application in colour (white) for flashing eaves, window frames and trim, together with inside ceiling.

- Roof - An estimated roof area of 600 sq. ft. over all.
- 10 gallons shingle paint necessary for this surface, colour gray @ $2.75 ----------------------$3.00

- Porch - Porch and four sets of steps
- 1 gal. of deck and porch paint, colour gray, to each wall, two coats, 1 gal. @ $3.85 ----------------------$3.85

Before the painting of the shingles is commenced send replacement of roof ridge boards. Further send caulking of flashing surrounding the chimney. The repainting of all mortar joints.

1 gallon of caulking @ $2.75 ----------------------$1.50
INTERIOR: Interior walls plastered red, fir floors. The class room walls, the portion above the wainscoting to ceiling, are discoloured and owing to the texture or finish of the plaster, encourages and permits dust and dirt to cling to these surfaces. The floor surface is worn and splintered in places and has a dismal appearance. Two cloak rooms are in a similar condition to the class room. The teacher's quarters, upstairs and down, plastered walls, same texture as that of the class rooms and needs re-decorating.

Class Room - Floor - 24' x 40' two cloak rooms 5' x 12'
I recommend the painting of these surfaces, an application of suitable stain, followed by a protective coating of Varnish. Material required:
3 gals. stain @ 4.00------------------------12.00
2 gals. Varnish @ 3.25 per gal.------------6.50

Plastered Wall Surfaces - Estimated 132 sq. ft. in school room and cloak rooms requiring 5 gallons of paint for two coats, colour Eye Rest Green, recommended, which affords the maximum light diffusion.
5 gals. Paint @ 3.10 per gal.-------------15.50

Ceilings - Lumber (V Joint) - 1080 sq. ft. in Class Room and cloak rooms. Previously painted. Surface should be thoroughly cleaned (washed). Two coats of Ivory colour or light Cream paint shall then be applied.
3 gals. of Ivory Paint @ 3.25-------------9.75

Wainscoting - There is a 4 ft. surround (V Joint) Interior walls of class rooms and cloak rooms, surface area 650 sq.ft. This surface shall be thoroughly washed, allowed to dry and given a one coat application of Varnish.
2 gals. @ 3.25--------------------------6.50

Sufficient Varnish in the above has been allowed for the doors and window trim.

Living quarters - Two bedrooms - Living room and Kitchen.
Floor areas - 560 sq. ft. Recommend the same material for these floors as the class room, requiring 2 gallons of floor stain @ 4.00 per gal.----------------------8.00
1 gal. Varnish @ 3.25----------------------3.25

Wall Areas - 1440 sq. ft. This will require a two coat application. Recommended colours, mauve for living room and bedrooms, colour Buff for kitchen, all white ceilings. Materials required:
4 gals. suitable paint, mauve @ 3.25------13.00
1 gal. suitable paint, Buff @ 3.25---------3.25
2 gals. suitable paint, White @ 3.25-------6.50

Ceiling requirements are included in the above. There is sufficient material allowed in above estimate to include staircase, which shall be given a two coat application of Varnish.

Total Material costs ------------------------$163.85

My estimates were intended to cover the exterior work only. It would depend whether the $250.15 balance over cost of material would be sufficient for labour as to how far the interior work could be carried out, if and when the work is authorized.

Your obedient servant,

On Dec. 13th, 1935 I forwarded a fairly detailed report on the Okanagan Indian Day School setting out the exterior and interior painting requirements of same, and had previously included $400.00 for this work in my 1936-37 Estimates, but at that time only the exterior work was considered. Later I ascertained that the cost of material for both interior and exterior would amount to $163.85 if purchased from the Tremco Paint Company, who I understand supply a great deal of this material to the Department on the Prairies and appear to have a special price to the Department. Probably such a purchase would cost considerably more. Out of the $400.00 estimated for the exterior work this would leave $236.15 for labour for both interior and exterior. However, if the matter received any consideration at all this year no doubt labour quotations could be secured.

The original paint work on the building was evidently poor material as it comes off in powder and it would ensure more satisfactory work to furnish a material of known quality and have the labour provided separately.

Sir,

Your File 164-5-5

I enclose herewith Voucher No.6908 in favour of Fred W. Beatty of Vancouver, B.C. for $108.60 covering paint for the Okanagan Indian Day School as authorized in your letter of the 1st of August, 1936.

Your letter indicated that preferably Indian labour be employed on this job and unfortunately it was not found possible to employ such labour during the summer recess, those capable being fully engaged with other work, and painting during the winter recess was out of the question on account of weather conditions, consequently the material was ordered in ample time to do the work during the Easter recess, but unfortunately instead of shipping the material from the Vancouver warehouse the paint Company sent it from Toronto and it arrived too late to undertake the work before the school re-opens and the material will have to be held until the school closes in July. This account is somewhat higher than the original estimate owing to Surcharge (Sales Tax) and that it was found necessary to obtain a sealing compound for the plaster walls as otherwise the cost of removing the old decoration off the rough cast plaster would have been prohibitive. It is expected that the cost of painting will be approximately $50.00.

Messrs Beatty Limited were requested to forward receipted freight account and it does not appear that the attached Bill of Lading constitutes a receipt. I have requested that this be forwarded to me and on receipt it will be sent to you, but I deemed it advisable to forward the accounts owing to the close of the fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, enclosing account for $4.18, covering the cost of supplies purchased for pupils of the Okanagan Indian Day School on Coronation Day.

No funds were specifically provided for the celebration of Coronation Day at Indian schools. We received many requests from different parts of the country but we were obliged to refuse favourable consideration to all of them. Under these circumstances, I regret that it will not be possible to pay the account which you submitted and it is therefore returned.

May 26, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith Voucher No. 42 for $4.18 in favour of Miss M. Hepworth covering a picnic lunch supplied in Vernon to pupils and former pupils of the Okanagan Indian Day School on May 12th, Coronation Day.

I may say that all rural schools were invited by the City of Vernon to participate in the School parade and Coronation festivities. As the Okanagan Indian Day School is situated sixteen miles from Vernon, it was necessary to provide transportation and Mr. Que, one of the Chinese lessees on the Indian Reserve, kindly offered to bring all the children in by truck. Thirty-two children were provided with a picnic lunch, the City of Vernon providing all rural children with their suppers.

I may say the children made a very creditable showing in the Parade and much favourable comment was heard.

As over 200 sandwiches were made, the cost per lunch per child amounting to only 13¢, I would respectfully recommend payment of the attached account.

Your obedient servant,

(Jas. Coleman),
Indian Agent.

/HM.

Sir,

I enclose herewith voucher for $27.00 in favour of F. Grist for labour painting Okanagan Indian Day School. When this work was undertaken it was found to be a much more difficult problem than anticipated due to the fact that all the plaster work in the building was extremely rough cast, very dirty and a great deal of it covered very badly with kalsomine, which was very hard to remove. Due to the sharp sand particles in the rough cast it was found that ordinary brush work would prove expensive as the brushes wore out quickly and it was hard to get satisfactory coverage. Consequently I supplied a paint sprayer at my own cost and the work proceeded satisfactorily except that the paint supply was found insufficient and it was necessary to secure additional paint locally to finish the job.

There has been some delay in closing out this matter due to difficulty in securing the accounts.

Your obedient servant,

Bernard F. Heary, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch.

Dear Sir,

I have requisitioned for desks. I shall appreciate very much receiving these as soon as possible, as nine pupils are working in great discomfort, and ten new little ones, I have had to refuse admission, as I have no seats for them.

I think, Sir, you will be interested to know, that we have started evening classes in English and mathematics. We opened on January 7th with nine brave men. A few more timid souls are talking of coming. I think they will get up their courage soon. I appreciate that it is no light thing for men—fathers of families—to take lessons from a woman, like little children—the English class is only third grade and under.

The eagerness of these men to receive even a little education is wonderful. The children, too, are showing great keenness for their school, and are progressing very favorably.

I do not mind any more losing the dispensary. The
evening classes, especially, are a source of great satisfaction.

I remain,

Yours truly

Re: Okanagan Indian Day School
Agency Ref. #164

With reference to Okanagan Indian Day School and the remarks passed by the teacher, Sister Patricia in the letter attached, I would suggest that the Department authorize the installation of a new larger size furnace at a cost of approximately $350.00 installed. The old furnace, which was never satisfactory, being too small, has now reached the worn out and burnt out stage that makes it useless. I understand from the firm that installed it twenty-five years ago, that it was the only furnace available at the time it was installed and was too small for the building.

I recommend that a wood-burning furnace be installed as it is not reasonable to have coal hauled 16 miles to the school when there is ample wood available on the reserve. I also request authority to purchase a new box heater at a cost of approximately $35.00 for use in the class room, it being required during the spring and fall and on rainy days for heating lunches, drying clothes and heat when the furnace is not required.

The remarks of the teacher regarding the condition of the class room is correct; the lighting is bad, the walls being a dark green and the ceiling requires fixing as also do the living quarters of the school and the extension of the building and one new set of steps is required at the girls' entrance.

I attach hereto an estimate of the cost of painting the school inside and out which appears to me to be somewhat
high, but the way conditions are at this time, everything is high and the cost of labour particularly so. Whilst it may be that I could purchase the material and pay the Indians wages for this work, I would advise that the Indians are all fully occupied in the vegetable fields and would not be available for the work during the busy summer season. I therefore recommend that this tender amounting to $11.00 for the full job be considered by the Department and that I be advised accordingly at the earliest possible date in order to get the job completed before opening of the school in September. If this tender is considered too high, then please authorize the work to be carried out to the best advantage so I will at least get the interior of the school painted by September.

Also requested is authority for the expenditure of $50.00 in the provision of new steps at the school entrance and mother minor repairs to the building. The steps are essential, one set having been removed as a hazard to the safety of the children.

Attached list covers the requirements as stated above.

(Alfred H. Barber)
Superintendent

I had authorized him to go down to a depth of 40 feet, and although this depth showed every indication of water for the last 20 feet, the gravel being saturated, no flow was reached and it would appear that possibly no water would be reached until the level of the lake was reached and this would have been probably 100 feet deeper and too deep to draw with a hand pump.

The condition encountered was amazing in that the site is 200 feet from the creek which has a good continuous flow and the terrain is of coarse gravel, and water in ample supply was expected at about 20 feet at the deepest. It would appear that the well spreads over a wide area through a deep strata or overburden of coarse gravel. The expenditure made in this regard is therefore a total loss which is very unfortunate.

(Alfred H. Barber)
Superintendent
Okanagan Indian Agency.
October 13th, 1948.

A. H. Barber, Esq., Indian Superintendent, Vernon, B.C.

Re: Water Supply - Okanagan Bay School

I have your letter of October 9th wherein you advise that although a well at the Okanagan Indian Bay School site was sunk to a depth of forty feet no water was secured. I also note that the well site is within 100 feet of a creek which has a fairly continuous flow. This stream presumably was the source of the water supply to the school in the past and it has occurred to me that providing the water is uncontaminated and volume and sufficient head are available the water supply problem for the school might be met by the installation of an hydraulic ram.

Information with respect to hydraulic rams is contained in a handbook of Practical Information on Irrigation published by the Provincial Department of Lands, a copy of which should be on file in your office. You will note from this handbook that a drop of five feet through a drive pipe of thirty feet would provide for a maximum lift of thirty-five feet and that by varying the length and fall of the drive pipe various lifts can be secured.

Will you please investigate and report whether or not the installation of a ram at this point would be feasible and desirable.

-En

M.E. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Okanagan Indian Day School

Following District School Inspector Davey's report of April 7th, with regard to the above-mentioned school, the Acting Superintendent at Vernon, B.C., was requested to investigate and report with regard to the necessary repairs. Mr. Hatt's letter of July 15th is enclosed, together with tenders from Joe Gabriel and Webster Brothers which indicate that the improvements required, all of which should be carried out this year, will cost $2,150.00.

Although it is unfortunate that no specific provision was made in the Estimates, the work is necessary and I would recommend that the Department endeavour to make funds available so that it may be proceeded with. It is hoped that with the appointment of a new Superintendent at Vernon, these matters will be attended to and that adequate provision will be made for any expenditures required.

Dear Sir:

File 10-11-5

With reference to your letter of May 9 - School Inspector's Davey's report of April 7 and Department letter of June 16 - File 833-5 (E.1).

I have inspected the Okanagan Indian Day School and enclose estimates from Joe Gabriel and Webster Bros. Please note that Webster Bros.' estimate was forwarded to Joe Gabriel and is included in his estimate.

I have found it difficult to get a contractor who is interested in this work, as the school is approximately 15 miles from town and there is no electricity so no power tools can be used.

Having gone over this work carefully, I find it is all quite necessary, and am unable to recommend that any of it be left until next year. However, should it be possible to complete this work this year, no further repairs should be necessary for quite some time.

With regard to the well, $435.00 was spent on this before and no water was found. I feel it would be quite easy to pipe water from the Creek, but as yet do not know just what length and size pipe will be required.

Yours very truly,

(D.M. Hett),

Sir,

I am requested by the Chief of the Inkameep band of Indians to ask the Department for assistance in order to start a school on the Reserve at Osoyoos. They have over 20 children of school age and he assures me that the majority of the Indians are in favor of the proposition. The Indians when I was there last were just starting on a hunting expedition but will on their return duly sign a requisition in council assembled for a school. The only difficulty I foresee is the distance from the nearest white settlement which is about eight miles but that can be overcome by appointing a male teacher if the Department is prepared to build a school house and pay the teachers salary. I have the furnishings at Enderby and could have them moved if so desired but I am also very hopeful that the Spallumcheen Indians will in the near future be willing to have a school on the Reserve.

Kindly advise.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Brown states that he has been requested by the Chief of the Inkameeo Band to apply for the establishment of a school on the Osayocs Reserve.

The census return shows that there are 20 children of school age and the Agent states that the majority of the Indians are in favour of having a school there. This is a small band, but a number of them are well-to-do, having considerable stock and making money out of their fruit, and I think they should show their interest in the education of their children by providing a building in which to hold the school. If they were willing to do this I would recommend that the Department pay the salary of the teacher.

There are no Indian schools in the Okanagan Agency and the white schools have objected to the Indian children attending.

The furnishings which were bought for Enderby are available and from the objections raised by the Indians at
at that locality to a school I would not recommend the Department to expend anything for buildings. The late Mr. Inspector Gummiskey, who reported on the question of schools for this agency, was in favour of the establishment of a boarding school there.

If the Osoyoos Indians are willing to do their part I think the Department would be quite justified in trying a day school there.

This unfortunately is the only school at present in this Agency so that no comparison can be made. I have secured the names of 71 children of school age living at the Hall-of-the-Lake reserve near Vernon. They are widely scattered and three schools are really necessary, but for the present if two were started on the reserve it would cover the larger part of it. One difficulty would be the accommodation for the teachers, who would be white teachers I presume. At the North end of the reserve...
there is a settlement of white ranchers who would probably give accommodation to a teacher for the school at this end and the Council-house could be utilised as the School house. At the South end there is no building which could be used for a school and the distance would be too great for a teacher to live at the north end and teach at the south end of the reserve, and there are no white people near.

While there are 71 children on the reserve, the proportion attending school unless compelled would be small, less than one half of this number, probably not more than 25 or 30 being likely to attend voluntarily.

At Penticton there is no difficulty either as regards the school building or accommodation for the teacher as both are available, and with the necessary authority of the Department the School could open after the summer vacation.

At Enderby we have the same conditions as at Penticton, but in view of the possibility of this Reserve being sold for 'Soldier Settlement' purposes, the matter will remain in abeyance at present.

It is therefore respectfully requested that instructions be forwarded to me to make the necessary arrangements for schools to be opened at Penticton and Head-of-the-Lake Reserves as outlined above, when a more detailed report could be made.

Dear Sir,

When the Indian delegation was at the Department yesterday, Manuel Louie, of the Osoyoos reserve, spoke about the school on this reserve. It appears that the Indians put up a building a few years ago and employed a negro teacher and paid him salary from money raised by themselves. As soon as the Department took over the school, the negro offered to return the money to the Indians, stating that he was paid by the Government, but the Indians refused in the majority of cases to receive the money back from him for fear, as Manuel Louie stated, that if they took government money for school purposes their reserve would be ultimately taken from them. It was explained to them that this was a nonsensical idea, as the people of Canada voted the money for Indian education and would not look to the Indians to repay the money in any form.

This School is very isolated and the teacher must of necessity live on the Reserve and there is no suitable house for her. Miss Hunter being of part Indian blood, she lives with a relative there, but few white women if any would care to do the same.

There are about 12 children living near enough to attend the School, and some of these come several miles which means that in Winter as soon as the snow gets deep they are unable to attend regularly.

The parents of the school children are anxious to have their children educated, while the other Indians resent having the School at all, so that it is kept up under difficulties, but as this is the only School in the Agency at present, I try to give it every encouragement possible.

Up hitherto the School has closed at 3 p.m. in Winter and only 30 minutes allowed at noon. The reason for this is that it is very desirable that the children have time to reach their homes before dark.

This Reserve is mostly steep mountain, and there are no doubt cougars and bear also occasionally on the Reserve last year they reported a grizzly also, and although they emigrated, the children are no doubt nervous after dark.

As a further instance of the difficulties here, when visiting the School last summer I found the teacher and children trying to drive out a brood of rattle-snakes from under the floor of the School. They were able to go through the floor during school-hours and disturb them. 3 snakes were killed and 4 were in the School room and though they were not afraid of them it was necessary to clear them out, which was done. These incidents are irrelevant and are mentioned in explanation of any departure from the Regulations.

Sir,

I have the honour to forward the following request from Chief Baptiste George of the Osoyoos Band of Indians living on Inkameep Reserve, Osoyoos No. 1.

The Chief states that he spoke to you in Vancouver regarding the necessity of building a small school on his Reserve and he was advised to take up the matter through this office. He is practically the only chief in the Agency who has consistently supported my attempts to educate the Indian children of the Okanagan and we have had a school intermittently for several years on his reserve. This has been carried on under difficulties as the reserve is rather remote from white settlement. There is no suitable building and it has been difficult to keep a teacher more than a year. So far the teachers have been part Indian and have lived in Indian houses. For a school we have used successively an old disused church now fallen to pieces, the priest's house which is also in bad condition and no longer used by the priest, and more recently an upper room in the Chief's house which is entirely unsuitable from every point of view. At present the school is closed as no teacher will accept the position unless a building is provided.

There are only eight or ten children of school age who can attend so that a large building is not required. The Church on the reserve has recently been renovated and repaired by Henry Parsons, a contractor in a small way living at Oliver, B.C., the nearest settlement to the Reserve. This man did a satisfactory contract on the Church and was later engaged by the Chief to repair several houses on the Reserve; the priest, Father Carlyle,
also offering him a contract to build a chapel on his ranch. I asked Mr. Parsons to give a rough estimate for building a small school with two rooms suitable for living quarters and he has submitted the enclosed rough sketch which he would complete for $750. If some building of this description could be constructed on the Osayoos Indian Reserve, it would meet all requirements.

We appreciate the two schools granted to this Agency, one on Okanagan Indian Reserve No. 1 completed and opened last January and another at Penticton No. 1 Reserve upon which construction commences this week. The Okanagan School includes a teacher's residence and cost approximately $5,000 and the Penticton school probably $3,000 (although I have not yet received advice as to the amount of the successful tender).

We have been using a small building on Penticton Reserve for the past year pending construction and as it is only two miles from Penticton there has been no difficulty regarding the teacher. These three day schools have done very satisfactory work, and have had a good influence on the Reserves, and I hope to see provisions made for one on the Spallumcheen Reserve at Enderby and another on the Similkameen Reserve.

For some reason this Agency was overlooked in the provision of educational facilities, (probably on account of Indian opposition which was more imaginary than real once the schools were opened), and I considered it my duty to remedy this condition, if possible, and obtain for the Okanagan Indians at least a small portion of the educational grant to the province.

I respectfully place these facts before you with a view to having a small school building constructed on Osayoos Reserve. It need not be of the usual type of day school building which is much in excess of the needs of this Band where the number of children will probably not exceed ten or twelve at any time. Request will be made later for the usual type of school both at Spallumcheen and Similkameen.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,

I am confident this School is a very satisfactory piece of work. The chief of the Band stands alone among the Chiefs of this Agency in strongly supporting education and he is particularly pleased with everything. Miss Wadell has been quite successful in the small Osoyoos school and seems to have the right temperament for the conditions under which the teacher must live. It is several miles from the nearest white neighbour with no means of reaching town except by chance Indian conveyance and on account of the isolation I did not expect her to stay very long as she is quite young, but she seems to have become accustomed to the Indians and the surroundings, and to be quite content as she has stayed two and a half years.

While I should be very sorry to lose Miss Wadell from the Osoyoos school, I realise the fact that sooner or later she would wish to live in a more settled locality.

REPORT of the ROYAL DRAWING SOCIETY'S 45th ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF DRAWINGS

MADE IN SCHOOLS AND AT HOME.

THE value of drawing in helping young people to gain knowledge of the world around and in developing their powers of observation and memory is well shown in this Exhibition. The majority of the drawings are "snapshot" in other words, recollections of what the draughtsman has himself observed, and the accuracy with which actual shape has been remembered is not less remarkable than the grace with which it is expressed, having regard to the age.

An outstanding feature of the work generally is the skill with which movement is delineated. Many examples of this are to be seen in the "snapshot" drawings and paintings that have been submitted.

H.R.H. THE PRINCESS LOUISE, DUCHESS OF ARGYLL, THE PRESIDENT, has given great encouragement to the practice of "snapshot drawing" by awarding special prizes for the best "snapshot" work in the Exhibition. Her Royal Highness usually awards two prizes, one for girls and one for boys, but the work this year is so good that, as was the case last year, The Princess has presented an additional prize.

The PRIZES FOR GIRLS Her Royal Highness adjudged to:

D. BARRETT (age 15, Luton, Red Book League) for pencil and brushwork drawings of animals in which the "knowledge and observation of action are very good."

D. COLLES (age 16, Parsons Mead School, Ashstead) for brushwork drawings of figures showing "good movement."

The PRIZE FOR BOYS was awarded to:

T. STERNDALE (age 9, St. Dunstan's School, Golders Green) for drawings of ships, a lighthouse, etc., in which there is "good perspective and observation."

Mrs. G. F. Watts' Prizes.

Needlework Book-cover Prize:—B. Davies (age 16, Simon Langton School, Canterbury), for "a beautiful bit of needlework."

Pictorial Posters.

H.R.H. THE PRINCE OF WALES was very interested to see the pictorial posters which were sent in. His Royal Highness thought them very good indeed and considered that they show a high standard.

Village Signs.

T.R.H. THE DUKE AND DUCHESS OF YORK thought that the Village Signs which they inspected, were well up to the usual high standard and that they were all so good, both in execution and design, that it would be difficult to pick out any particular one for special mention.

Their Royal Highnesses were very amused by the efforts of the small children and considered that the drawings by a child of three were particularly good for her age.
SUMMARY OF THE JUDGES' REPORTS ON THE EXHIBITS.

Pictorial.

Taken as a whole the work reached a high standard and was well up to the level of previous years. This was especially evident in the "snapshot drawings" of figures and animals where appreciative attention had been given to a single factor. The best of these were very good, excellent work was done in surface description and plant drawing, and the village signs were extremely well executed and carried out. In the landscape class there was a higher average and much of the work was most praiseworthy.

Snapshot Drawings.—The quality of the "snapshot drawings" of figures, animals and landscapes has always been outstanding but this year it was even better than usual. The figures were well observed, movement was accurately rendered and much of the work was very good. The rendering of movement was particularly good in the junior classes.

Animals.—Animal drawing of animals who had devoted some of their time during the year to studies of nature, therefore increasing their knowledge of animals, were inevitably the best. A number of students showed an ability to make animals appear as they really have done but more attention has been given to serious study of details. The work of those who have studied animals such interest and was very well executed. It is essential that the animals be seen out of doors. Good surface description is essential and obtrusive outlining should be avoided.

Figures.—A number of figures were submitted by the pupils who received them. There was much good work; the general form was well observed and the figures were generally realised. Structural knowledge was lacking in many cases. Much of the work and the judges considered a greater number of detailed studies of parts. In a few cases the judges thought that a greater number of detailed studies of parts would have improved the work. The judges found a tendency to over-emphasise the outline and the drawing showed a tendency to over-emphasis of detail. A good deal of attention is paid to drawing the figure with the brush point, an admirable descriptive medium.

Portraits.—Portraits were submitted by a number of pupils. Greater success would be obtained if more attention were given to structural study, especially of the skull. Students of facial expression were highly commended by the judges and really good work is often likely to fail to receive recognition.

Landscape.—Some very commendable work was sent in and there were many examples of the highest quality. The judges were pleased at the attention given to tone, line and colour. It was pleasing to see the subject approached with such serious consideration as well as with a keen sense of observation. The judges found a number of very good candidates. The formation and movement of clouds is a good guide to the weather, and this should be considered when painting landscapes. Clouds overhead are nearer to the spectator than those on the horizon and should be drawn as though they were upright to the earth. In the rendering of trees some candidates set themselves too high and this detracted from the effect.

Original Illustrations.—Ambitious subjects were often attempted, and in a number of cases with considerable success. The judges thought that more attention should be given to expression and posture, suitable grouping and pleasant harmonious colour. A few candidates failed to secure their full effect owing to cramming too much into their compositions or confusing the eye. Originality and freshness of approach and execution are essential and sincerity is best secured by relying on ones own resources. The judges thought that more attention should be given to the suitability of the subjects selected, as the results of the examination test of the Society's Examination Committee. Some pupils tried to illustrate scenes which they were unable to draw. In such cases the subject should always be written on it when made.

Shading.—Knowledge of light and shade is so essential to good painting that the judges wished to draw attention to the fact that wherever an object gives mercy, the silhouette should be dark and the object itself light. To convey the appearance of volume projection or recession is the main distinction of the art of shading. To convey the appearance of a close group it is important to deal with the dark parts correctly as with the lights which often seemed to receive an undue share of attention.

Still Life.—Still life work showed sensitive appreciation of tone-values and there were fewer drawings of complicated and uninteresting groups. It is helpful to pupils to give them a limited range of objects to arrange. Attention should be given to the arrangement of the groups they are to paint, as it heightens their interest and helps to keep them interested. In arranging still life groups the judges thought that successful students the group should be made up of not more than two objects, their colour should be harmonious and the light source should be clearly defined. The dark ground should be a subdued value of the main colour and help to increase its effect, and the details, tone and colour of objects placed behind should be kept in harmony with the overall effect of the picture and not appear too forward in the picture.

Surface Description.—It was pleasing to note the attention which this important subject, the rendering of drawing, was receiving. There was a large entry, the average of the work was good and much of it was excellent.

Decorative Compositions.—Many well planned and original designs were sent in. Some were rich and strong in colour, while others were weak and pale. The background harmonised with the subject as included to be crude or the background was not carefully thought out with respect to the covering of the main design. In designing a decorative composition the subject should be correctly interpreted and the general character of the plant should be preserved. Abstract and geometrical designs were also sent in.

The judges found difficulty in assessing this class owing to the lack in many cases of necessary information as to the purpose of the design. Where such particulars are not given the design often receives a lower award than it otherwise might gain.

Plant Drawing.—A strong class with much good work both in pencil and brush. In some cases the pencil work was rather too fine and the hatching too heavy, and freehanding was sometimes overdone. Sensitive appreciation of colour was shown generally, though a few drawings were spoiled by heavy local colour or the use of colours which did not harmonise with the subject.

Lettering.—Some of the work was good, but other examples were marred by overcrowding. In some instances the work suffered from being too hard to read. Brown ink is encouraged and varying tone in the letters the best quality of process black ink should be used.

Overseas.

Drawings of overseas scenery, landscapes, plants and animals were sent in from many parts of the Empire. The work generally showed marked improvement, especially in the drawing of figures. Some capital "snapshot" drawings were received, the only life were recorded and the figures were very well drawn. The colour was generally good throughout, but greater attention needs to be paid to variations in local colour brought about by the effects of light.

Architecture.

The standard this year was distinctly higher. Less ambitious subjects were attempted but there were some very good examples of architectural subjects. The work was well planned and a commendable feeling for the quality of the material was perceptible in some of the drawings and some attractive small studies of details were received.

"SNAPSHOT DRAWING."

"Snapshot drawing" is the easiest and most fascinating of all forms of drawing. It is easy because it is so natural, being the very process that the youngest child employs when he draws spontaneously; so fascinating because in its advanced form it involves some of the highest qualities of the mind and requires the co-operation with the eye and brain of the highest concentration. All its forms, simple, intermediate and advanced may be practised by children of from 5 to 6 years old onwards.

Briefly it is drawing from recollection things observed by the draughtsman. Its value consists not merely in the fact that it is "drawing from delight," but that this joy in drawing is obtained by stimulating and developing the intelligence of the pupils and training them to think of the "why and wherefore" of the things they see in everyday life.

It is sometimes thought that "memory" and "snapshot drawing" are the same thing under a different name. That is not so; there is a great distinction between the two. A memory drawing is not necessarily a reproduction of the observer's own mental picture; it may be a recollection of a picture or drawing by someone else.

The distinguishing characteristic of "snapshot" draughtsmen is the power of expressing movement in free flowing lines. The success with which quite young children are able to show movement and vitality in their drawings is often the despair of older and more practised draughtsmen who are unversed in "snapshot drawing," for if you do not practise the representation of movement when you are young it is difficult to acquire the art in later years.

A photograph of, say, a breaking wave or a moving figure or animal offers, back, life, yet a "snapshot" drawing by a mere baby may possess it. Why is this? A "snapshot" photograph and a "snapshot" by the eye record two different things. The photograph represents what occurs in a path of movement in an instant of time, and during that brief period the moving object is to all intents and purposes stationary, so that what you really get is arrested movement. A "snapshot" by the eye shows the path of movement itself. It is a broad generalisation by the draughtsman representing in a single impression a series of moments of movement.

A moving object is part of a moving world; the universe is always in motion. Young people live in a world of moving things; they take pleasure in drawing them and if encouraged, attain remarkable facility and success in infusing vitality into their work. Many striking examples will be found in this Exhibition.

Annual Exhibition, 1934.
(Memorial to King Edward VII. and Queen Alexandra)

"Better than ever" was the verdict of many visitors after seeing the 45th Annual Exhibition organised by Mr. T. R. Ablett, H.R.I.

The Guildhall Art Gallery, in which the Exhibition was held, by kind permission of the City Corporation, was crowded with visitors, the attendance averaging nearly two thousand a day. Many Heads of Schools and Art Teachers brought parties of their pupils to see the work, and a feature that excited special interest was a series of albums containing "snapshot drawings" taken from examination papers of schools connected with the Society in Africa, Australia, British Guiana, Canada, China, Chile, India, Japan, the West Indies, etc.

A few selections from the many Press Notices are given overleaf.

N.B.—Early preparation for the 1935 Exhibition is recommended.
Surprising Competence

The work reaches a surprising degree of competence, particularly the brush drawings of plants. Every work shown is worth looking at.—*The Times.*

A Revelation

If you want to see what youth can do, go to the Guildhall. The Exhibition is something of a revelation in its variety, ability and freshness.—*Daily Telegraph.*

Striking Originality

Widespread attention has been attracted by the high standard of many of the children's drawings to be seen in the Exhibition. Why, it is asked, do children show such striking originality of design?—*Morning Post.*

A Splendid Exhibition

It is a fine exhibition, a splendid exhibition. There are drawings and paintings and needlework that will delight your heart. None of this problem picture, Cubism and "What does this mean?" I suppose the artist must know stuff. Just plain, straightforward pictures of men and women as we see them, ships that could conceivably sail, dogs that look as if they could bark, and cats that you would expect to howl o' nights. The vast majority of these drawings and paintings are the work of children. Little children. Frankly they are first-rate. Really first-rate.—*Daily Mail.*

First Step to Success

On the walls of the Guildhall Art Gallery hang hundreds of sketches full of action, phantasy and colour. Mr. Ablett, the founder of the Society, says: "Encourage your child to draw—even if it's only scribbling—and you will help him up the first step to success as an engineer, airman, doctor, scientist, or whatever profession he chooses."—*Daily Express.*

Girls' Keen Observation

However times may change, children's reaction to things is always much the same. Boys being chiefly interested in boats, engines and the like, tend to give us greater variety by following the latest inventions and sports with their pencils. I would credit the girls, however, with keener observation, which is the basic aim of the Society in its encouragement of "snapshot drawing."—*News Chronicle.*

Fruits of Snapshot Drawing

Here are thousands of drawings from many parts of the Empire, most of them done by the Society's method of "snapshot drawing"—that is, drawing from recollection after observation. The claim that this method stimulates the power of expressing movement in full-flowing lines is well sustained by the exhibits which achieve representation while avoiding copyism and that imitation photography which is still, in many quarters which should know better, imagined to be the artist's function.—*Liverpool Post.*

Remarkable Snapshots

A high level has been reached this year, and the success in catching the movements of living subjects is more pronounced than usual. The snapshots from memory are remarkable.—*Manchester Guardian.*

Value of Drawing

Exhibits that fill two large galleries and many volumes of "overflow" efforts of only slightly less merit are ample proof of the value of drawing in helping young people to gain knowledge of the world about them, and in developing powers of observation and memory.—*Birmingham Post.*

Wholesome Freshness

These very youthful artists not only draw and paint what they have seen with an accuracy that is remarkable, but succeed splendidly in giving a wholesome freshness to their work. In their sheer virility many of the efforts would do credit to older and more experienced hands.—*Yorkshire Telegraph.*
Realism and Action.

Spontaneity and simple grace are the keynotes of the Exhibition. Particularly attractive are colour studies of horses at work and leisure, and to some of these has been imparted a note of realism and action not always coming within the ambit of the experienced artist's power of observation.—Glasgow Herald.

A Welsh Success

Fourteen year old Jean Cratchley of the Plymouth Preparatory School, Penarth, has carried off one of the chief awards. She has won Mr. Ablett's coveted prize for a series of brushwork plant drawings showing a remarkably sensitive appreciation of colour for one so young.—Western Mail.

Ireland's Gold Star

Much is being made of the drawings by tiny tots and they are certainly extremely interesting but the really remarkable feature of the show is the high quality of what one may call the more "adult" works on view. It is all the more gratifying, therefore, that Ireland has carried off one of the principal awards in the Exhibition, a Gold Star for still life.—Irish Times.

Dear Capt. Barry:

Word has just been forwarded to me that there will be a vacancy in the Incaneep Indian School at Oliver next term and I beg to make application for the position.

I have a school at present, and am being very successful but it is a non Catholic centre, and I am anxious to get in the Catholic work.

Mr. Miller, my inspector visited me my first day here, but hasn't given me a second visit yet. I will send you a copy of his report as soon as he visits me again, which I expect to be very shortly.

I have my own boys in Vancouver College at Vancouver. While it is a great blessing for which I am thankful it is difficult for me finance them and keep a home here too.

I would like the Penticton school, should Miss Weydert decide to give up teaching in the future but I will be very happy if you will think well enough of me to let me have the one at Incaneep.

While the press and the British authorities have made a great deal of comment on the exhibits, I am inclined to the opinion that they have a rather vague impression as to the type of Indian executing the work, and there is a great difference between the nomadic Indian and the rather highly civilized type on Osoyoos Reserve with cars, radios, modern farming machinery and displaying on the surface very little difference from his white neighbor. While granting that his work has the great value of originality and novelty, in my opinion, it falls far short of what he is capable of performing. To visualize a half-naked aboriginal doing the work is one thing and to see a clean cut, excellent mannered and educated youth doing the work is another and might prove rather a disillusionment and consequently I would prefer to go into this matter further before making any recommendation involving expenditures.

Later the boy went to London where they were exhibited at the Royal Drawing Society and received honorable mention. The artist's name is Francis Baptiste and he is now about 19 years of age. He has distinguished himself as a Canadian to attain the honor of having one of his pictures, "Indian Boys in Training," acquired by the Royal Drawing Society for its memorial collection.

HAS OWN STUDIO.

In 1939 Francis Baptiste was sent to Santa Fe, New Mexico, to study Indian art. At first the boy was very homesick, and he found difficulty in adjusting himself to the new life. He soon recovered, however, and his mixing with young artists stimulated his interest and for a long time he was producing pictures with a new and inspired aspect. Upon his return to Canada, Baptiste, Chief Baptist George, who was so interested in the boy's work and so pleased with what he had accomplished, so many awards, built him a studio of his very own. His studio is situated on the Inkameep Reservation, and Francis is continuing his work in his native surroundings.

"Indian Boys in Training," was selected out of thousands to be taken to the Empire Exhibition, where it was viewed by the King and Queen, and in the summer of 1938 it was exhibited at the Empire Fair in Glasgow.

MANY PRIZES.

Another picture, "Canadian Nativity," was painted on birch skin. It was awarded the bronze star in 1938 at the exhibition of the Royal Drawing Society in London, then came a copy of this picture which placed in exhibit in Toronto and Montreal, where it received high praise from art critics. In 1937 Francis received a silver star for his picture, "St. Francis and the Birds." Both his pictures were offered to one of the companies competing in the Dominion Drama Festival and were accepted.

A portfolio, portraying the life of the Okanagan Indian, ancient and modern, and to which Francis has contributed much of his artistry, was exhibited at the famous Clzek Juvenile Art Centre in Victoria when he was nine. Later this was sent to Prague, where it was shown at several schools.

For five years now, Francis has contributed much to the realms of art, and he is unique in that he and one would never think that so many honors could have been acquired by a boy who likes to paint and draw.
PRIDE OF RACE IS ENCOURAGED

Anthony Walsh, Teacher at Inkameep Indian Reserve, Describes Native Art

A fascinating talk about what is being accomplished in restoring and developing among the Indian children of the Inkameep Reserve near Merritt, in the Okanagan Valley, love and understanding of their own traditions, legends, poetry, dances, songs and history was given by Mr. Walsh to an interested group gathered in the lounge of the Windermere Hotel yesterday to hear Anthony Walsh, teacher at the Inkameep School.

"Developing Indian Pride of Race" was the subject of Mr. Walsh's address. He approached the discussion of Indian native art from this angle, opening his talk with a delightful "composite" story of the Nativity written by his native pupils and with some symbolic pictures which revealed the religious nature of the people.

In the first part of his address, Mr. Walsh described the Indian settlement, which consists of about 105 people. Although not far away, Mr. Walsh was almost isolated until two months ago controlled, so far as internal management was concerned, by the old chief who was in his ripe age of ninety. Fishing, hunting, the management of small orchards and garden furnishes all they needed for food and clothing. Before he died the old chief said to Mr. Walsh, "Teach these young people to be good men and women before all else, showing his deep concern for the future.

SKETCH OF EACH CHILD

Mr. Walsh then gave a sketch of each child in his school indicating the stage of maturity and artistic ability of each, and their unconscious inheritance of native culture. As an illustration of his work he gave the pupil who brought in the largest collection of Indian songs he had heard a copy of a book containing a full list of the Inkameep melodies. Living very close to nature the boys and girls were naturally observant and small birds引起了and a lot of interest in his schoolmates as well as his teacher by faithfully illustrating the Ojibway songs he had picked up while following his father's plough over the field.

Although the Indians follow the curriculum set by the Government, Mr. Walsh makes sure that the children have fifteen minutes daily to creative work when the individual abilities of each boy and girl are given free expression and encouragement, with special anxiety to bring out any characteristically Indian art or ornamentation. During both the poetic and dramatic instinct of the children he gave two plays, written by himself and performed entirely by the Indians, masks being worn in lieu of special costumes.

Mr. Walsh was introduced by Miss Alice Ravenhill, well-known Victoria authority on British Columbia Indians, who was present, and among the interested members of the audience was Major L. Bullock-Webster, of the community drama branch of the Department of Education.

Indians Tell Tale of Nativity

The Tale of the Nativity, as told by the Indian children of the Inakameep tribe of the Okanagan, has been published by the Committee to Promote the Revival and Development of the Ancient Gifts of the Native Tribes of British Columbia, in an effort to see these ancient tales of the true Canadian story again in life.

Anthony Walsh, in charge of the Inakameep school, many years ago saw that these Indians possessed dormant artistic gifts, and that with their revival they would contribute greatly to Canadian art and culture. He realized that these innate abilities, artistry, craftsmanship and dramatic talent of the Indians were dormant, until today the results are apparent in all their work.

It is only those who are most progressive who progress the farthest along the artistic path is a young lad, Sis-hulk, whose drawings and paintings are known throughout Canada. A tribute to their excellency lies in the fact that an entire exhibition, containing only his animal pictures, drew much interest and attention in Victoria, when they were exhibited at the Windermere Hotel here last June, and in that they are still remembered by the Royal Family, who viewed them in 1914 after their exhibition by the Royal Drawing Society in London. This young artist has also done illustrations for the Lieutenant Governor and Mr. Hamber, and many other well-known local people, the Inakameep version of the Nativity shown being one. It is the story of the birth of Christ and His early years, as adapted by these Indians to their own environment and civilization.

Throughout the tale the charming, simple folk-lore of typical Indian stories is evident.

The money derived from the sale of the book will go to remuneration of Sis-hulk for his artistic contributions and to the advancement of the natural talents of these peoples.

A. M. D. Fairbairn, private secretary to His Honor Lieutenant-Governor Hamber, sent a congratulatory letter to the editor and wished Sis-hulk every success in his future career. Another letter from Mr. Fairbairn, Secretary of the Department of Welfare Training, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, commends the book and its illustrations.

Dear Sir,

In the administration of Indian Affairs one of the most important problems confronting the Department is the repression of intemperance among Indians on the Reserves. In view of the peculiar character of the duties of Indian Agents and particularly, moreover, as they are frequently obliged to act in a magisterial capacity, it is essential that they should themselves be above reproach and that they should observe the strictest propriety in their personal conduct in every respect. So serious is the view taken by the Department with regard to this subject that any well-founded reports of inebriety will result in immediate suspension and probable dismissal.

It should be understood that this letter is intended for the advice and guidance of all Indian Agents and that no personal application is intended.

Our Indian Culture

Recently I had the good fortune to hear a lecture by Mr. Walsh upon the work he is doing among the native children at Inkameep, B.C. Mr. Walsh said little in the conventional sense, what he did was to act out five short folk plays written for his pupils and nothing like all folk literature does, of bears and birds, sun, wind and earth, the oldest ties man has with his world.

Mr. Walsh is more than a teacher; he has the restrained yet kindling fire of an artist. A man who is keen and aware of the work he has labored at untiringly for the last ten years. He believes implicitly in the tradition and nationalism of the Indians and has dedicated himself to the work of showing this ancient people their worth and to the white man for what they are, a race endowed with an art, and a history that are unique.

In these native children he has studied closely and when he knows so well, he has discovered a natural poetry and humor, a sense of music and rhythm of the dance. The larger aim of his work is to raise the status of Canada's finest settlers by teaching them how to develop their native culture and so adjust themselves to the difficult conditions and demands of a white man's world.

He spoke of his first meeting with the chief, a spare figure of dignity with flashing black eyes and an ancient dignity. When he was about to begin teaching the old man said earnestly, "Mr. Walsh, I want you to teach my people how to meet the world upon its own terms."

Farms, villages, Indian reservations, and cities of all States contribute the talent to be seen at this year's National Folk Festival. Here and hundreds of American Americans have joined in the Nation's Capitol celebration of the arts which is song and dance.

For the first time with matinee and evening performances daily, these hardworking performers give an informal and spontaneous the expression of the folk forms which makes up American folklore.

From Colorado to the Carolinas, from New England to the Southwest, communities have sent their best performers to participate. Some enter on an invitation basis, selected either because of their outstanding competition at local and regional festivals or because of their travel expenses or are sent to Washington for the first time by the State Education. None receives pay for his participation.

Only one full rehearsal has been held. The performers have studied performance of professional standards and have been instructed to perform as they would in their own environment. They are not to take part in a formalized program but to present themselves as they would in their own communities but to have a good time and to enjoy themselves. It is to be a festival in the true sense of the word, a festival for everybody, marking for both spectators and performers a new experience.

Over the seventh successive year, a presentation by the Kiowa Indians, famous for their paintings and carvings will open each of the four evenings of the festival. The Easterners have this opportunity of watching the Indians who were old when Columbus set foot on our continent.

THE PURPOSE AND AIMS OF THE NATIONAL FOLK FESTIVAL ASSOCIATION AND ALLIED COMMUNITY FOLK FESTIVALS

By Sarah Gertrude Knott

THE NATIONAL FOLK FESTIVAL

Seven Annual National Folk Festivals have been held in the United States since 1934 in St. Louis, Chattanooga, Dallas, Chicago, and for the last three years in Washington. The Eighth Annual National Folk Festival will be held in the nation's capital May 1, 2 and 3, 1941, under the sponsorship of the Washington Post Folk Festival Association.

OBJECTIVE

The objective of the National Folk Festival is to bring together annually the varied racial groups from the different sections of the United States, with their characteristic folk expressions for a people's holiday and merry-making. In addition to the joy the Festival gives to participants and audiences, it reflects the social life and traditional customs used since early days. Through the inter-change of distinctive folk-songs, music, drama, dance, and folk arts, it offers an opportunity for greater understanding and better understanding and more tolerance which should result in stronger national unity. It hopes to create consciousness of the richness of our traditional folk-art, the basic art, which would undoubtedly help to inspire classic art built on these roots.

WHAT THE PROGRAMS INCLUDE

The programs include folk-song, music, dance and other traditional expressions handed down orally and traditionally, presented generally by rural people who have been their guardians. They reflect the age in which they were used. A National Folk Festival is a twenty-five-year-old age which has told its different stories and has reached by modern civilization. The best possible example of survival by groups that could work out a way to get to the festival have been included. But as chances become less and less auspicious for survival, efforts for revival seem necessary. At the Seventh Festival it was no longer possible to present some of the survivals which appeared on the program of the first festival in St. Louis. The participants who knew the songs traditionally were too old to come. So a few groups with revivals or with dances taught, have been accepted. Though the programs especially feature rural folk, some urban groups have been admitted because the American square dance and other traditions are needed and used by city dwellers as well as rural folk. Many people who now live in cities know and love folk-song music and dance because they are of rural birth and background.

INCENTIVE FOR COMMUNITY FESTIVALS

The chief interest of the National Folk Festival Association was, at first, the development of an annual National Folk Festival, to show a cross-section of the folk-expressions of the major racial groups which have contributed most to the folk-life of the United States.

At the beginning, community folk festivals were held only in the state or region where the National Folk Festival was presented in connection with the development of its program. For these festivals the best representatives were sent to the National. As time has passed, we have seen the importance of them for their own value to the community. We have encouraged festivals regardless of participation in the National. We have recognized the part the traditions of old and new Americans can play in community and national life. The National Folk Festival can serve only a limited number of participants since it is held only in one city each year and lasts only three days. The community festival arouses in each community an interest in and appreciation of the deeply-rooted, basic cultures peculiar to that community. It offers many a chance to participate and even more the opportunity to witness performances. It gives the community an additional cultural leisure-time activity, which costs little money and can be carried on by local leaders.

For several years there has been a growing interest in community folk festivals, especially among rural leaders, many directly or indirectly given incentive by the National Folk Festival. Those mentioned below have been directly influenced.

Before the first National Folk Festival in St. Louis in 1934, eighteen community festivals were held in the Arkansas and Missouri Ozarks with May Kennedy McCord, of Springfield, leader. Prior to the second Festival in Chattanooga in 1935, regional festivals were held in four different sections of Tennessee. Fred W. Colby of Nashville, Tennessee, has carried on...
the work throughout the state since then. Preliminary to the third event at Dallas in 1936, thirty community festivals were held in Texas, and four in Missouri. Also in that year, four Indian festivals were held in different sections of Oklahoma. In connection with the festival in Chicago in 1937, several festivals were given in Illinois and Wisconsin.

In the last three years, as a result of interest created by the National Folk Festival in Washington, a number of schools in the District have had school festivals of one kind or another. Six thousand and one school children have attended each festival in Washington, with the result that teachers and students have become more aware of the various traditions. Delaware has had a state folk festival for three years; Upper Marlboro, and Prince George's County, Maryland; Virginia, the University of West Virginia, and other communities have presented local festivals. The annual Mountain Song and Dance Festival at Asheville, North Carolina has been carried on for the past fourteen years directed by Beacon Lamar Lunsford, member of our National Executive Committee, and pioneer in the folk field. Pennsylvania has had state folk festivals in addition to numerous community ones under the direction of George Korson of Bucknell University, also a member of our National Executive Committee. A California folk festival was staged in 1939 at the Golden Gate Exposition by M. J. Pickering, Business Manager of the National Folk Festival.

The interest created in many communities has continued, and festivals are regularly held in a number of places though not in all where they have been begun. Most of the leaders have set up and insisted upon definite standards. In such instances the work has gone forward. But where the leaders did not stick to genuine folk traditions, the plans have fallen through. It is our hope this year that many more leaders in different communities throughout the country will make plans for annual state or community folk festivals and that they will hold to the best in the traditions of their communities.

EXPERIMENT IN NEW MEXICO

Last year, in connection with the United States Coronado Cuarto Centennial, in New Mexico, as Supervisor of Folk Festivals, I had the opportunity, in cooperation with Arthur L. Orme, of the University of New Mexico, of proving what could be done under proper conditions. Two hundred folk festivals were held in the various Spanish-American and Anglo communities with a few Indian festivals on the Navajo reservation.

State-wide Educational Program Carried on For Six Months. If the folk festivals in New Mexico had been planned purely as entertainment, quickly arranged and soon over, they would have made no imprint on the state, but being thoughtfully planned and executed after a period of six months preparation, many of the traditions, which otherwise would have passed from the scene, were realized for continued use.

The state-wide plans were made in the fall of last year, through the cooperation of teachers and community leaders in most of the schools and communities. After Christmas the plans were put into operation and continued until spring, when the festivals began.

School Plans. The music teachers in schools taught the folk-songs of New Mexico, as a regular part of the music course. Physical education directors emphasized the folk-dances. Legend and folk-tales were featured in the class room. Many projects were worked out by teachers of different departments to make the students of the state more conscious of the charm and worth of the traditional heritages of the Indian, Spanish-American, and Anglo. In a number of cases, the teachers had the students collect legends, tales, superstitions, etc., to record for future use. Through this plan new impetus was given to the use of the rich folk legacies. New appreciation was felt of the privilege of living in a state with three sets of folk-traditions, expressing three philosophies of life.

There can be no doubt that the state taken as a whole still has more survivals of traditional expressions, and they are more generally used in everyday life than any other. Yet modernity is taking its toll even there. The Coronado Cuarto Centennial Folk Festival program came at the logical time to give new impetus.

Community Activities. In many communities "set-togethers" were held for several months for the adults. Teachers in the community, and people generally, came together to learn folk-dances or singin'-games. Leaders who knew them taught others or if all knew them, they enjoyed a weekly evening of folk-dancing. By the time spring had come many had learned again the dances that were giving way to newer forms which did not serve as well.

"Old-timers" met each week to live over early days in New Mexico.

The 16th century Spanish-American folk-drama of the Miracle and Morality variety was revived. This type of traditional drama has served as New Mexico's "Little Theater." It met the need which professional drama could not meet in a state of isolated communities. It has been used since the Spanish-Americans came into the region in the early 17th century. In many communities where they were ceasing to be done, they were again presented through the incentive given by the state-wide interest in the return to the traditional.

Though good roads now bind together the isolated communities of the state, the Spanish-American in New Mexico is still economically bound to the soil. Until that condition is radically changed the traditions will be needed. No other form of recreation can take the place of the deeply-rooted folk-traditions which have served the state for four hundred years.

New Mexico Plan Logical for Other States or Communities. Similar plans could be carried on in many states or communities, differing according to the needs. Many contend that we are a standardized nation. We are in many ways. We are making too much of an effort to make alike each community, rural or urban. Individual differences and needs should be recognized. There are still many rural communities besides New Mexico where actual living conditions have not changed much with the rapidly advancing civilization around them. There are communities who organized recreation through the National Recreation Association, City Recreation Departments or Extension Divisions of State Universities have not been able to reach. In some communities where these plans reached, often their splendid programs fail to utilize the leadership and natural heritages of the folk of the community. Frequently leaders do not fully realize the possibilities of such programs. A part of the program for rural recreation surely should be one which stresses the importance of the inherent dignity of rural culture, as well as one emphasizing the fine points of urban culture. It should prepare rural folk for more joyous living, by utilizing their own resources.

During the National Recreation Association Congress in Cleveland last October, I attended the discussion sessions where rural culture and recreation were discussed. In every meeting there were those who were making use of folk expressions. But always there were those who felt that stressing the use of folkways, folk art and dance was going back to the "horse-and-buggy" days. They did not recognize how much older than that is folk-culture. They did not think of it as the fountain source and well worth the return for inspiration and refreshment. These genuine natural expressions are as greatly needed now as when our pioneer forefathers used them as they cut their way through wildernesses to establish houses here. We are pioneering again searching for better ways of life in a civilization much more complex than our fathers found here. We need simple, wholesome recreation to help us keep our balance in these confused times, more, perhaps, than early colonists needed it to lighten the load and offset the prosaic, monotonous days of early trail-blazing.

The community festival is a logical way of giving a needed recreational activity, of utilizing and dignifying rich heritages to serve a definite need now generally felt.

SIGNIFICANCE OF PROGRAM

If the traditional expressions existing in the United States had no roots in the past, no possibility of life in the future, the joy that comes through their use today would be sufficient reason for national and community folk festivals. But there is value to the folk-traditions in addition to present recreational worth. There is more to the folk-song than the tune of it, more to the folk-dance than its form, more to the myth than the story it tells. In our traditional expressions are recorded the social life of early America, and the growing, changing life for America. They reflect the "living history" of our country, the struggles and joys we have shared together in establishing a new nation. Through them we glimpse the life of native lands from which our peoples have come. They reach far back into the days of unrecorded history and tell us the customs and beliefs, the longings and desires of those days.

We cannot blind ourselves to the fact that the foundations of our basic cultures should be projected into the future because their forms are fundamental. Our cultural and social life, for rural and urban people, will be less rich if we lose them. As they have served the past and are used in the present, so will the future need them. They should not be blown away with a changing civilization.
This is a significant age of transition between an older, simpler America and a new, more standardized, uncertain one. If our traditional expressions are to be continued into the future, a conscious effort must be made. The chances are that many will not be continued as an unconscious art, as they have been in the past. The machine age and industrialism have brought an end to many folkways and traditional customs in other countries. The folk-lore of every nation passes through three stages. In the first, it is in its prime. No outside influence has touched it. In the second, it is on the down-grade because of outside influence, but it still has vitality to respond to stimulus. In the third, there is no life upon which to build revival. We are in the second stage today.

We cannot expect these expressions to survive in their purest forms when conditions that brought them into being, or went then alive thus far, radically change. The isolated communities in their purest form are now connected by radio, good roads and automobiles with the outside world. Rivals in other forms of entertainment have appeared where once the traditional alone held sway. So a new attitude toward them must be taken if they are to remain to enrich the soil from which they spring. They must be emphasized in order that survival may continue longer and revival come sooner, while there is a "living" pattern to go by. While they are vital forces in our lives they should be incorporated in the roots of our culture.

We are thinking much about conservation of forests, wild life, and land. Land can be restored, forests brought back, but once life has gone out of the people's stories, songs and dances, the intimate reflections of their deepest sentiments and feelings, they cannot be restored to their original form. Perhaps some day in the future, folk-ways shall have given way to standardization, man will try to piece together the fabric of song, dance, and legend, better to understand life today. But the spirit will be lost. Now, while the traditions endure, is our opportunity.

Since there is at present, almost the first general interest in traditional heritage in the United States, we should take advantage of the situation and make organized efforts to preserve them, as we are trying to preserve our forests, wild life and land. Scholarly work in collecting and recording is necessary for history and invaluable to leaders of folk groups, but it fails to pass on the vital spark which oral transmission gives.

With old ways of life breaking down in many lands, the United States has a vital part to play as guardian of European heritages. Unless the attitude in Europe changes, and if we continue our democratic way of life, they is the place where they must be preserved. Many of the nations of the Old World with civilization much older than ours have had revivals at one time or another, but usually after living forms had passed. Fabrics had to be pieced together from records and books. The original spontaneity was gone. We should not make this mistake.

COLLECTING FOLK-MATERIALS DATES BACK TO ANCIENT DAYS

Interest in collecting traditional materials of the folk goes back, we know, as far as the "Vedas", and has come on down, with great gaps, through the time of Christ to the present day, each collection reflecting certain periods. Until modern times however only comparatively few scholars were attracted to folk-lore, though earliest literature made use of the lore of the folk which had been handed down orally. As printing facilities became better, the traditions which had long been transmitted by word of mouth found their way more and more to the written page.

There has gradually developed a widening of interest in folk-lore in all countries. Among some of the European countries, especially Scandinavia, in the early 17th century, started collections and established museums of folk materials. It was not until the middle of the 19th century that folk-lore really attained the status of value as a science recognized by scholars generally in western Europe and America. In 1846 the term "traditions" or "popular antiquities" became "folk-lore," then came the coinage of the word by Thomas, of England. This new word "folk-lore" was more usable, more living. No doubt it played a part in opening the way for continued interest in traditional forms, then would have been possible through the use of "antiquities" which seems to have no connection with the present.

SCIENTIFIC AND LITERARY INTEREST IN THE LAST HUNDRED YEARS.

During the latter part of the last century, through incentive given by the scientific methods laid down by the Brothers Grimm, of Germany, folklorists from England, Germany, France, Scandinavia, America and other
