countries have made comparative studies analyzed and classified myths, legends, folk-tales, superstitions, music and dance. The chief concern of many of the immediate followers of the Grimm Brothers was to trace the history of the human race through scientific study of folk-lore. There was no other way except through archaeological findings to open the closed doors of the past.

Other scholars in these countries, for more specific literary purposes, have analyzed, classified and collected the folk material. Generally they have it with materials from purely the literary standpoint, with no thought of putting them back into circulation, or making them serve a purpose except for those interested in literary pursuits.

Since the turn of the present century, however, there has developed a steadily growing interest in collecting folk expressions among musicians, dancers, and lovers of folk-tales for their own value. These later collectors are interested in making use of them or making them available to others. Just as scientific and literary interest in folk-lore spread in earlier days throughout western Europe and America, at about the same period, so this more recent humanized approach came to the different countries.

MORE RECENT GROWTH OF INTEREST

Cecil J. Sharp, of England, had vision beyond collecting. He saw value in folk-lore for social purposes, and recognized the need for revival since many of the original forms had ceased to exist in England. He was a musician as well as a literary man. His collections, with music for songs and directions for dances, made in England and America about thirty years ago, and his interest in teaching started a revival in England which spread to the other European countries and reached America. His contribution was teaching and "showing", as well as collecting.

The first collections of British ballads and folk-songs in the United States by Child, Kittredge, Randolf, etc., others included texts of traditional ballads collected and discussed from the literary standpoint with little or no music. More recent collections have been made covering the traditional associations of the Indian, British, Spanish-American, German, French and other Old World heritages, also Negro, lumberjack, cowboy, miner, sailor and other New World creations, which have contributed to American folk-life. Many of the first collections here were not made with any idea of continued use as folk expressions.

Within the last ten years, however, there has been an increasing interest in usable songs, music and dances, including music for the songs, directions for the dances, as well as myths and tales for use. Music teachers, physical education directors, rural sociologists, recreation leaders and others, have begun to draw upon these sources for materials. Even anthropologists and scientific folklorists are beginning to humanize their approach. This broadening of interest has not only been in evidence in our country but in Canada, Mexico and some of the South American countries as well as in Europe.

During the last ten years there has been a tendency on the part of the peoples of many nations to return to the simple fundamentals of folk-song, music and dance. National or international folk-festivals have been held in England, Sweden, Hungary, Germany, Russia, Canada, Mexico and Bolivia, as well as in the United States. The National Folk Festival preceded most of those mentioned. In 1935 I attended the International Folk Dance Festival in London. The objectives were much the same as those of the National Folk Festival, comparative study, recognition of social values, and creating better understanding through interchange of folk-dances. There was such recognition of the value of these objectives among the European countries that the majority of the governments of the participating nations officially sponsored the groups.

As a new group after group moved across the stage of Royal Albert Hall with their characteristic dances I thought, "That color! What strength! What simple natural grace! Here they represent sixteen different countries. In my land they are all part of one nation over which the Stars and Stripes wave. What opportunity is ours!"

IMPORTANCE OF FOLK TRADITIONS TO NATIONAL LIFE

We feel that the National Folk Festival, which has sunk its roots deep into American soil, has a part to play in national life if war comes to our doors. Battles are not won by battle-ships or airplanes alone. The spirit of the people counts. With a foundation in the various communities already laid, we feel that we can do much in helping our people hold their balance "behind the lines." We can play a part in "defense from within."

We are being guided in many ways now by successes and failures of nations in the present European struggles. At first dictators paid no attention to the folk expressions. Hitler, however, has made use of the traditional expressions of Germany through his youth program for ten years or more. He has bound together the German youth into new soldiers, through folk-song, music and dance. They have played an important part in helping him build up a strong national and racial consciousness and pride. Hitler has been a broad sympathizer philosophy. It has been the opposite of what should be the ideal use of folk traditions in a democratic nation. But his plan does show the strength of folk expressions as the ties that bind.

Russia has had somewhat similar programs, with the same general objectives. Both Germany and Russia have used the traditional expressions or revivals as propaganda to develop totalitarian states. The dictators recognize the sentimental approach which folk expressions give them.

Czechoslovakia and Finland Used to Strengthen Loyalties. The folk traditions of Czechoslovakia kept alive the spirit of the country for four hundred years during its dismemberment before the nation was again united after the World War. The fighting spirit of the Finns owes a debt to traditional ties that gave them common ideals and purposes.

England Saw the Need in Governing Peoples of Diverse Cultures. England's scientists saw the value of traditions a number of years ago. One of the earlier scientific folklorists, Taylor, writing about 1870 and speaking of England said: "She who rules over vast territories of infinite diversity...of all stages of culture cannot possibly govern without taking into account the motivating powers that actuate them." Folklorist Hartland, Taylor's English contemporary, said: "That a waste of precious human lives might have been saved in our manifold dealings...if we had been acquainted with their mode of thought." Since that time, efforts have been made by scholars and scientists in our country, as well as in others, to understand the individual characteristics of various peoples which are best expressed through folk traditions.

TRADITIONAL TIES UNITE THE AMERICAS

INVITATION TO OUR NEIGHBORS

Until very recent times we looked to Europe for our cultural and economic patterns. The startling events in Europe have made us see the wisdom and the necessity of developing cultural and economic relations with nations in this Hemisphere. At least we are opening our eyes to see that we are really related and tied together through strong bonds.

Since its beginning, the National Folk Festival has included on its program many of the traditions common to Canada, Mexico, South America, the Islands and the United States. We recognize that many of the traditional expressions in the United States bind us to these countries as well as to Europe. Recognizing the value of strengthening ties and interchange of traditional heritages, last year the Territory of Hawaii was represented on the Festival program through the cooperation of Dr. Martha Beckwith of Vassar College Folk-Lore Foundation and Miss Alice Brown of Honolulu, Hawaii. This year we are eager to have South America, Mexico, Canada and the Islands send guest groups to the Eighth Annual National Folk Festival. This offers a logical medium for interchange between these countries.

The common ties of language and traditional customs are the strongest ones that we have with Canada, Mexico, South America and the Islands. Strong are the language and traditional ties of the English, French, Scotch and other stocks common to America and Canada. Invaluable in understanding Mexico and South America are the Spanish language and Spanish-American traditions which have existed on what is now United States soil for four hundred years. The "Good Neighbor" policy should begin at home. When we really come to recognize, appreciate, and claim as our own the cultural heritages of our own national family with its varied stocks, it will be much easier to establish genuine cultural relations with kinsmen in other countries.

The Cultural Division of the State Department and the Pan American Union have broad programs for developing better cultural relations between the Americas. The National Folk Festival is most concerned with the folk traditions and their cultural significances to our own country. However, we feel that with the development of appreciation of our own folk heritages and the insight into the distinctive character of each group, will come a better basis for understanding our neighbors whose presentations we are eager to include on this year's program.
It is high time for the United States to recognize the worth of folk traditions in democratizing our peoples, in creating better understanding, more tolerance, and stronger national unity. Few nations, if any, have as many living folk expressions as we have and none has the variety which our many racial groups give us. Each group within our borders has its own peculiar temperament, its own distinctive quality and philosophy of life. Inherent characteristics are expressed in folk-song, music, dance, legend, folklore, etc. An intelligent use of these traditions now would undoubtedly go far in making possible a richer cultural life in peace times, and a more united front in the emergency of war.

If totalitarian states have found the folk traditions of value in developing esprit du corps; if Czechoslovakia, Finland and other countries in peace as well as war-time have found joy, strength and spirit in them; if England has recognized the importance of traditions that express racial temperament, prejudices and traditional ways of life in governing her people, is it not well for the United States with its many groups of diverse philosophies of life, which may be used for well or woe, to consider well its folk traditions? May this not be a way to understanding and unity?

From the vantage point of the mid-twentieth century, we see many significances in the individual differences of our peoples which we could not have seen earlier. Time had to give us perspective. If the white man in early days had better understood the Indian's nature...but then, he could not until he glimpsed it in his age-old ceremonials through which his soul speaks. If we had known the burdened soul of the Negro in bondage...but then, we could not until we heard his soul cry through his spirituals, which grew out of that burden. If we had become better acquainted with our Spanish-Americans whose traditions have roots four hundred years old on what is now United States soil...but it took a world crisis to attract attention to them. As last we are beginning, along with other older nations, to understand that folk traditions are not just "relics of an outlived" past. They are vital today.

Dear Miss Knott:

Your letter of February 20, addressed to the Minister of this Department, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

I have read with interest the purpose and aims of the organization you represent, outlined in the memorandum enclosed with your communication. I can state without hesitation that I have nothing but words of commendation for the work in which your organization is engaged, and I feel confident that the Eighth Annual Folk Festival, to be held in Washington May 1, 2 and 3, will prove of more than ordinary educational and inspirational value to the people taking part therein.

February 20, 1941

Mr. T. A. Crearer  
Minister of Mines & Resources  
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. Crearer:

We are holding the Eighth Annual National Folk Festival in Washington May 1, 2 and 3... I am sending you under separate cover a program of last year's Festival and a Statement of Aims, from which you will see what we are trying to do.

From the program you will see that twenty-seven states and the Territory of Hawaii were represented last year. This year we are inviting Canada, Mexico, South America and some of the Islands to send guest groups.

We feel very sure that the National Folk Festival in the last seven years has done much in bringing about better understanding, more tolerance and stronger national unity through an interchange of the folk traditions that express the inherent characteristics of us all, so this year, since there is such need for us to understand our neighbors to the north and south, as well as those in the other America, we have invited these groups.

Each year for the last seven years we have opened our program with the Indian presentations from the United States. We have had on the programs during these years, the Kiowas from Oklahoma, the Mescalero Apaches, the Zunis, the Navajos, the Sioux, The Blackfeet and Cherokees.

We have had the cooperation and confidence of Mr. John Collier and many others in the Indian office here.

This year we heard through Frederick Koch, of the University of North Carolina, who gives a course each summer in playwriting at Banff, of the work of Anthony Walsh at Inkameep. We know from what Mr. Koch has told us and from material we have had which shows the splendid work of Mr. Walsh, that he is doing a genuinely outstanding job there. We are eager to have him bring a small group to the National Folk Festival to represent Canada here. We know that we shall have to have your approval to do this. When you have looked over the material which I am sending, will you please

CONSTITUTION HALL, MAY 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 1941
let us know if you would give us your approval of the plan?

The National Folk Festival is not a commercial organization. It is a cooperative, cultural, educational one, as you will see from this letterhead. It would not be possible for us to have a budget large enough to pay the expenses, even of the groups who come from the widely separated communities of the United States. This has been done for the last seven years by civic and educational interests in the state or community from which the group comes. We have found that Chambers of Commerce, tourist associations, etc., are often interested because it calls attention to their particular community and shows that they have a part to play in the cultural folk life of the United States.

I had a letter this morning from Mrs. Daisy C. Miller, Box 2, RR 1, Oliver, B.C. She is interested in cooperating with us in working out plans, but first we must await your approval.

Of course, the Indian traditions are of great importance to Canada, as well as to the United States. Their traditions, of course, are most ancient and are most real. The Indian office here and the Indians themselves have felt that it is a good thing, as they take on the white man's civilization for them to recognize and appreciate the splendid racial background which they have. Their history and their background is, of course, told only through their traditions. We believe that many of the people of the United States understand the Indians better since they have met them as audiences in the National Folk Festival. They have felt the deep significance of the Indian tradition as they have never felt it before.

We think that Mr. Walsh is especially forward-looking in doing creative work based on the old Indian traditions. We have long believed that such a thing should be. In our Country we do not know of an instance comparable to what we think Mr. Walsh is doing at Inkameep, so we would be proud, indeed, to have him on our Festival.

All good wishes.

Sincerely,

Folk Festival Will Reflect New Spirit of National Unity

By Sarah Gertrude Knott
Founder and Director,
National Folk Festival

IN these days of suspense abroad and anxiety at home it is easy to understand the upsurge of interest in all things American. This new nationalism, whether it finds an outlet in popular patriotic song or in the products of American dress designers, represents a return to the roots of our fathers taken for granted in times of peace but sought as a refuge when trouble comes. Then the veneer of sophistication wears thin, the superficial class barriers disappear and the foundation stones upon which our land was built stands revealed. We find that Americans under pressure from a totalitarian foe are strangely similar to Americans under pressure from civil strife, as in the 1860's, and from tyranny, as in 1776. And so, even while we prepare to defend ourselves against future threats, we bend our thoughts irresistibly drawn to the people and the customs of the past.

Thus the eighth annual National Folk Festival, opening May 1 at Constitution Hall, seems to come at an unusually opportune moment. The thousands of Washingtonians who have attended the festival during its three previous presentations here will, we hope, welcome its return.

A People's Holiday

Those unfamiliar with the festival idea, we feel sure, will enjoy this unique opportunity to hear and see authentic folk events and performances. May 1, 2 and 3, the varied racial groups who gather each year from many parts of the country for this people's holiday. Through the interchange of distinctive folk songs, dances, myths and music comes a better understanding of our greater tolerance, which should result in stronger national unity.

The songs and dances included on the programs are presented for the most part by rural folk who have been their guardians. But because no concerted effort was made until recently to preserve, the folk arts and traditions may die out with the gradual spread of movies and radio into rural areas. Where survival seemed unlikely, efforts for revival became necessary. So it is that the festival occasionally accepts the contributions of groups who have revived some rural folk expressions.

Festival leaders realize the value that the American square dance, for example, can have for city dwellers. We need simple, wholesome recreation, and we keep our balance in these confused times, more, perhaps, than early colonists needed it to lighten the load of trail-blazing.

UNTIL recent times we looked to Europe for our cultural and economic patterns. At last we are opening our eyes to the necessity of developing national relations in this hemisphere, to whom we are bound by ties stronger than mere geography. Since the beginning the National Folk Festival has included on its programs many of the traditions common to Canada, Mexico, South America, the islands and the United States. Each year the Territory of Hawaii was represented on the program. This year the festival organization is eager to have other neighboring folk groups join us.

We are being guided in many ways now by the successes and failures of nations involved in the European struggle. Hitler has made use of the traditional expressions of Germany through his youth program. Folk song, music and dance have played a part in the attempt to build up national and racial pride. Much as we may hate the use to which he has put them, we must admit he has shown the strength of folk expressions as the ties that bind.

Esprit de Corps

Totalitarian states have found the folk traditions of value in developing esprit de corps. And democratic nations like Czechoslovakia and Finland found joy in them, during peace as well as in wartime.

FROM the vantage point of the mid-twentieth century we see many significances in the individual differences of our peoples which we could not have seen earlier. Time had to give us perspective. If the white man in early days had better understood the Indian's culture—but that he could not see—slipped him in the age-old ceremonials through which the Indian's soul speaks. If we had known then the potent soil of the Negro in bondage—but that we could not until we heard his soul cry through his spirituals, which grew out of that burden. If we had been better acquainted with our Spanish-Americans, whose traditions have roots 400 years old in what is now United States soil—and yet it took a world crisis to attract our attention to them. At last we are beginning to understand that folk traditions are not just "relics of an outlived past." They are vital today.

Since there is at present a general stirring of interest in American folklore, let us take advantage of the situation and make organized efforts to preserve our cultural heritage as we are trying to preserve our forests, lakes and wildlife. Scholarly work in collecting and recording is necessary for history and invaluable to leaders of folk groups, but it fails to pass on the vital spark which oral transmission gives.

Living History

There is more to the folk song than the tune of it, more to the folk dance than its form, more to the myth than the tale it tells. In our traditional expressions are recorded the life of early America and the growing, changing later America. They reflect the living history of our country, the struggles and joys of the people together establishing a Nation. Through them we glimpse the life of foreign lands from which our people came. Without them our social life will be less rich if we lose them. As they have served the past and are used in the present, so will the future depend on them. They should not be blown away with a changing civilization.

New York, March 8—With the German advance through Bulgaria to the Greek frontier growing, signs of British-Turkish preparedness for Balkan eventualities, the ancient Greek city of Salonika again may become the scene of decisive events.

This old city, founded in 315 B.C. and originally named Thessalonica after a sister of Alexander the Great, has been ruled by Greeks, Romans, Saracens, Normans, Emperors of Armenia, Venetians, and Turks, and was bequeathed for by Slavs, Bulgars and Germans.

It was from Salonika that the Allies launched their blow on Sept. 1915, which ended in the first break in the front of Germany's lines—the capitulation of Bulgaria on Sept. 6.

March 11, 1941

Mr. Harold W. McGill
Director, Department of Mines & Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Mr. McGill:

I greatly appreciate your letter of March 4th. We so greatly appreciate your interest and are glad you think the work we are doing is of value.

We deeply regret, however, that you feel that an exception to the general rule cannot be made in the case of Mr. Walsh. Of course, we understand full well how it is to break a rule. As you say, there will be so many others who will feel that the rule ought to be broken for them. However, if there is ever justification for breaking a rule, we feel that this is one of them. Mr. Walsh has begun a plan in Canada that seems to me to be very far-reaching culturally. As important as are the immediate necessities which confront us all in our war-time activities, we absolutely believe that we cannot look just to the present. We must look to the future. If activities like the National Folk Festival, and like Mr. Walsh's plan, have to give way now to the immediate necessities, the chances are that somehow during the struggle which probably faces us we are likely to lose our spirit to carry on at this significant transition period between the old ways of life and the new in Canada and the United States.

Then we do believe, as we said in our previous letter, that this gesture of goodwill between Canada and the United States is an extremely important one, since our Festival is held in the Nation's capital and since it has its roots in every state in the United States, the coming of this group from Canada to our country would have genuine significance.

I do not know how it is in Canada, but I know that in the United States we are just coming to properly evaluate the Indian traditions which are, after all, the only history book which we can read to find out about the first Americans. In our country I know the Indian traditions are giving way to the white man's civilization, but they are so basic and fundamental, not only for us here in the United States, and you in Canada, but for people everywhere, that surely Mr. Walsh's idea of using these traditions in a creative way is one of the ways, at least, to carry them down into the future.

CONSTITUTION HALL, MAY 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 1941
future.

I do not know of any such splendid plan in our country as Mr. Walsh has. We are so eager to take advantage of the work he has started there to give incentive to people in the United States to see the possibilities of what could be done here.

I have just had a letter from Mrs. Daisy C. Miller, Secretary of the Okanagan Society for Research and Revival of Indian Arts and Crafts, which was formed last week. The coming of this group to meet our Indians in the United States would no doubt give interest to further work along this line.

Mrs. Millar and a number of people in the community of Oliver are interested and are cooperating with Mr. Walsh in his plan to get to us.

We believe this goodwill tour from Canada to the United States has so many significances that I cannot put them all on paper, but I know from the tone of your letters that you will understand.

Mrs. Millar has been in touch with Mr. Crearer. Won't you please get together and reconsider the idea of giving permission to Mr. Walsh and to us to have him with us?

Greetings and all good wishes from all of us.

Sincerely,

SARAH GERTRUDE KNOTT

Ottawa, March 14, 1941.

Dear Miss Knott:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of March 11, in which you ask us to review and reconsider your request that Mr. Anthony Walsh, teacher at the Inkameep Indian Day School, be permitted to take part in the National Folk Festival to be held at Washington May 1, 2 and 3.

I may state that immediately following receipt of your letter of February 20, the desirability of having Mr. Walsh visit Washington was very carefully and very sympathetically investigated, in the light of existing events and regulations. The conclusion was reached at that time that in view of all the circumstances it would be almost impossible to grant this request.

Miss Daisy C. Millar, Oliver, B.C., renewed this request in a letter to the Minister dated March 6, 1941, and again the matter was reviewed and considered. You can readily appreciate how difficult it is for the officials here and for myself to refuse this permission, for a number of reasons. First of all, we believe that the work in which Mr. Walsh is engaged should be encouraged in every way possible. Secondly, we believe the program arranged by your organization is comprehensive and of more than ordinary cultural and inspirational value. Then again, we are anxious at this time that everything

Miss Sarah G. Knott,
Director, National Folk Festival,
Suite 101, Munsey Building,
1529 E Street Northwest,
Washington, D.C., U.S.A.
within our power should be done to bring about the closest possible co-operation between the people of Canada and the United States. In view of these reasons, the requests which first reached the Minister have been considered with unusual care and from every possible angle.

We are confronted with the fact, however, that for economic and other reasons, a number of requests from Canadian citizens who desire to visit the United States are refused daily. Each one of these applicants feels that from the standpoint of health or for some other reason he has a peculiar claim on the sympathy of the Government. Refusals, therefore, always result in a certain amount of dissatisfaction, and I am convinced that from the standpoint of Mr. Walsh's work and his future usefulness in the Indian service, it would be very undesirable for him with a group of his pupils to make the trip from Oliver, B.C., to Washington this year.

It has occurred to me that if it is the intention of your organization to organize regional festivals in the western States at any time, it might be comparatively easy to have Mr. Walsh visit the States of Oregon or Washington. I am, however, submitting this thought wholly by way of suggestion.

May I embrace this opportunity to express the hope that your festival of this year will be successful and satisfactory in every sense?

Yours very truly,

Your letter of January 5th advising of the approval of the appointment of Mr. John Atwood as teacher of the Inkameep Indian Day School reached this office on January 7th. This office endeavors to deal promptly with applications for positions in our schools but despite this and the fact that the Department does not delay in taking the necessary action, it usually takes a week to ten days to get a decision. In this particular case Mrs. Atwood called at the office on January 5th regarding the application of her husband for the Inkameep school and I assured her then that I had no doubt whatever but that Mr. Atwood would receive the appointment. The Minister is in receipt of a report from Mr. Albert Millar, President of the Okanagan Society for the Revival of Indian Arts and Crafts, which reads in part as follows:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your report of the 17th instant with reference to the resignation of Mr. P.J. Kiernan as teacher of the Inkameep Indian Day School and to enclose herewith copy of his resignation which has been forwarded to the Department from which it will be noted that he closed the school on the 11th instant.

It will be noted from his letter that the reasons given for his resignation were lack of fuel and dissatisfaction with living conditions. He complained that the furnishings of the school left much to be desired, particularly in regard to the bed, there being no pillow, two very thin grey blankets and a mattress that has rotted, apparently having been used by the Indians when this school was not occupied. Also, that the cook-stove needs some repair as it lets the ashes fall out on the floor creating a fire hazard and that the sill of the school door has become so worn that the snow blows through the gap.

These complaints are substantiated by your report above referred to and it is not understood why the supply of fuel at this school should have become depleted to the extent that when the teacher returned from his leave there was not more than twelve hours supply inside the school and nothing but a few large knots outside. It should be realized that in the Interior where wood is depended on for fuel that the opening of the fall term at this school should see one full school year's supply of wood on hand at the very least in order that it may be seasoning fit for use and it is astonishing that the condition complained of and admitted should have been allowed to develop. If the Baptiste family showed signs of delay in the supply, the services of another Indian family should have been sought or, failing this, the white dealer in the locality approached in the matter.

It is noted that you requisitioned the Department for mattresses, etc., for this school in October, but you should be aware that such requisitions should be passed through this office and it is probably for this reason that the matter has not been dealt with by the Department. You should make out a complete requisition and re-submit this with local quotations to me in duplicate.

(over)
In respect to the proposed enlargement of this school, I am of the opinion that as this will be one of the first schools that will be replaced when the building program re-opens that no alterations should be made unless it becomes much more evident than it is at present that this is necessary. If any enlargement was required, I would consider that the classroom itself is much more in need of alteration than the living quarters which, while admittedly are small, could be much more comfortable and attractive than they appear to be at present. There is, no doubt, a necessity for reflooring all the rooms in this building and you should secure the cost of having this work done and adjoining a small porch with door to the classroom door in order to prevent the wind blowing directly on the pupils when the door is opened in the winter. Meanwhile, it would appear to me that renewal of the door sill would remove a great deal of the condition complained of by Mr. Kiernan. In regard to the cook-stove, I do not understand why the purchase of this was left to Mr. Walsh. It is evident that his choice was far from satisfactory and that before long a more adequate cook-stove will be required. The matter of repainting the interior of this building is one on which you should report, submitting estimates of the cost of material and labour. It is presumed that you will endeavour to trace the two Coleman lamps and have them repaired and put into working condition.

Regarding the water supply for this building, if it is not found possible to develop any system immediately by way of digging a well or piping the water from the spring mentioned, it may be possible to install a small wood "V" or metal flume from the spring. I understand that there is also another spring a short distance north-east of the school on the hillside which may be worth developing and possibly it could be brought into use at a low cost.

Unless Bishop Johnson has a nominee for the position as teacher at this school, there is no one in sight at the present time, teachers being at a premium, and for this reason we have had to put up with some very inferior individuals for these positions, but this should not deter you from proceeding to investigate and deal with the requirements of this school in respect to furnishings, equipment, repairs, alterations and water supply, bearing in mind that extensive alterations are not indicated in view of the temporary nature of the structure. This would also apply to having on hand an adequate supply of wood seasoning for the time it will be required which we hope will be in the near future.

(over)
In respect to locating the school at some other point, it would be necessary for you to make a survey of the number of children of school age and pre-school age at the village at Osoyoos Lake, the present location of the school and the village around the Church in order that the largest number of children will have the least distance to travel.

When a new teacher takes over this or any other of your schools, please have an inventory made of all the equipment, school books and material and have the teacher sign the same, checking it over with him when he leaves the school or commences the summer holidays if there is any likelihood of his not returning. In this manner, you will not only have a check on Departmental property but will also be kept fully informed as to the amount and condition of the furnishings and thus prevent complaints and discussions such as we have had in recent weeks in this connection.

KT

Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter No.215-10-9177 of December 22nd ultimo and 215-10-95 of the 8th instant together with copies of correspondence with Mr. Albert Killar, Oliver, in respect to conditions at Inkameep Indian Day School, I now advise that I visited Inkameep Day School on January 12th instant arriving about two p.m. with the intention of interviewing Mr. Kiernan in regard to conditions at the school and to go over the contents and furnishings of the school with him. I found three boys playing outside the school who informed me that the teacher had gone to town the previous evening and had not returned. I entered the school with a pass key and found the school and quarters in a very untidy state. Towels from the hooks on the walls were on the floor, books, pencils, etc., under desk, a pile of rubbish and debris from the wood behind the heater and I would say the place had not been swept for several days. The living quarters were little better. There was not more than twelve hours' supply of fuel inside the building and nothing but a few large knots outside.

I went over to see the Chief, Narcisse Baptiste, and saw his son Charlie who confirmed the fact that the teacher had not returned from town the previous night. I returned to the school and waited for the Chief who was driving cattle up from the lower place. When he was finished feeding he came over and I spoke to him regarding his failure to have the wood delivered to the school as he was asked to do and usually does each year, although at his leisure. He stated that the boys had all been too busy with the cattle but that Charlie had been bringing in a few blocks until they could get the supply cut. I told him that this was not good enough. The teacher was there to teach their children and they were paid to supply the wood and if they did not they could not expect a teacher to stay or to rustle his own wood. He replied, "perhaps we have been too busy and were going to get the wood as soon as we could at times but the teacher told me he was not coming back after Christmas". I told him to get four cords cut and delivered at the school at once and stated he would get the boys at it the following day.

I suspected from the attitude of the Chief and his son Charlie that there was something more behind the situation than I had gathered.

On returning to Oliver, I made enquiries for Mr. Kiernan, thinking he might be sick or something, but failed to locate him, but ascertained that he had stayed at the hotel the previous night and had stated he would be in again that night. I left a message for him to telephone me at Penticton as soon as he came in.

The following afternoon, Thursday, he telephoned me at.......
at Penticton and informed me that he was leaving and was just going out to the school to get his belongings and I arranged to see him in Penticton the following day at which time he stated he could not possibly return to the school and was leaving for Vancouver that evening, and regretted not having given a month's notice.

I suggested that he call at your office in Vancouver and he agreed to do so. He also stated that he had tried to speak to the Chief in Oliver that day and the Chief had walked away from him after saying the boys were cutting wood today. On my asking if he had had any trouble of any kind, he replied "No, but perhaps the children had gone home and told their parents something I may have said which they did not like" and said he had told them that he was running the school and not their grandmother (the Chief's wife). This may have had something to do with his failure to get any co-operation from the Indians.

In the evening I wired you as follows:

"Teacher at Inkameep School resigns and left for Vancouver apparently difficulty over fuel and general conditions etc. I found school closed on thirteenth and he informed me today could not continue and will call at your office. Will forward my report as soon as possible."

I would state before dealing with conditions at the school that Mr. Kiernan, whilst I believe he may be a very good teacher, was, in my opinion, totally out of his element at this school and did not appear to make any effort to make himself as comfortable as possible under the circumstances and I would say was not the type to care for himself in a way that it was necessary for a bachelor in such a situation. I noticed that there were no blankets on the bed, only a thin rug of some kind, and I asked him if this was all the bedding he had. He replied it was and that he used his overcoat and dressing gown and a piece of buckskin he found to help out as he did not think he should have to supply his own bedding.

I have to advise that requisition was made for a new mattress, two blankets, floor rug and an easy chair and same was forwarded to the Department from this office on October 4, 1943, and October 15 and no word has been received from the Department to date.

Inkameep Day School was built by the Department in 1924 at a cost of $947.00, size 30'x16', this includes the class-room, approximately 20'x16', and teacher's quarters—kitchen 8'x9' and bedroom 8'x9'. There are three doors in the kitchen, one opening directly outside, one into the bed-room and the other into the class-room, with one window. The kitchen is furnished with a very small cook-stove with a fire-box that will hold one small stick of wood. It is actually five inches wide and totally inadequate. This stove was requisitioned for
and purchased by Mr. Walsh in 1940. There is an old kitchen cabinet of a sort badly in need of a coat of paint; one very old and dirty wash hand stand, which should be thrown out; one old table, size about 30"x20"; one set of six shelves, home made. The floor is covered by an old congoelum rug purchased in 1941, but worn out. There is one old wooden armchair. The bed-room is furnished with an old, single, iron bed, a very dirty mattress, a very old dresser with broken mirror, and a congoelum rug in fair shape on the floor. Both the kitchen and bed-room are very cramped, there not being space in the bed-room for a chair, whilst there is not room for two chairs in the kitchen, and whilst Mr. Walsh kept the quarters very neat, although very cramped, he appeared to be quite satisfied. These quarters were very dirty when I called on Mr. Kiernan and he did not appear to have made any effort to improve them in any way. However, the condition of the floor must be overlooked in the winter time as there is no porch at either the classroom or kitchen entrance and one steps directly out of the snow into the room, carrying snow or mud.

The lighting is furnished by a two-burner coal-oil lamp. However, there are two Coleman lamps at the school which I have not seen, but have just recently been informed that Mr. Walsh put them in the attic (?) as he could not keep them in mantles which broke every time the door opened.

The water supply is very bad, being carried over in pails from the well at the Chief's house two hundred and fifty to three hundred yards away, or from a spring up the hill almost the same distance.

As these quarters are at the present there is no comfort whatever, but they could be improved a great deal by the throwing out and replacing of most of the furniture now there and most certainly a new mattress will have to be supplied. As to bedding, I am of the opinion that the teacher should furnish this and feel that most would prefer to do so. However, this may also be necessary.

The partition (wallboard) between the kitchen and bedroom should be removed, thereby making a fair sized kitchen and an addition built on for a decent sized bed-room and a porch screened with wire for the storing of fuel in the winter and to sit on in the summer. Some cupboards for storage could also be built on the veranda facing twelve feet on to the length of the school would provide the additional space. A porch and cloakroom should also be built at the school entrance. At the present snow and mud are carried into the classroom. Also when the door opens the full effect of the whole outside enters the building.

The floor of the classroom is badly worn and very thin and should be renewed. It is impossible to keep it clean and sanitary in its present condition with the wide cracks and the wide space around and under the door requires sacking be shoved against it to keep out the draught.

To sum up the whole situation, it must be admitted that the living quarters are very small and cramped, the furnishings.......
furnishings are old and there is no upholstered easy chair for the teacher's use and a new mattress is required for the bed. Some teachers would be able to make the place far more cosy and comfortable than others and would requisition for such things as paint, a quart of which used on the furniture would make a great difference.

The water supply is the greatest inconvenience and it does not seem possible to get the Indians to co-operate in digging a well. In fact they hire white men to dig their own. In my opinion it may be difficult to locate water at the school site and the cost of digging and cribbing a well may be high, say $3.50 per foot. In view of this I believe it would be far better to move this school to a new position approximately one-half mile north where water could be obtained from Inkameep Creek by pipe direct to the school. At the same time the school should be enlarged to provide better quarters, a new floor laid and a porch built.

I would refer you to Mr. Coleman's letter of July 21, 1936 addressed to the Assistant Indian Commissioner, which covers the water situation at the school very fully. However, in my opinion I believe it would be better to move the school closer to Inkameep Creek.

With reference to your enquiry of 18th March, 1941, and November 4, 1943, re furnishings, etc. at this Agency's day schools, I have to advise that this return was made to you on November 16, 1943.

(Alfred H. Barber)
Indian Agent.

Replying to your letter of the 13th instant (file 41203-1) with reference to the report of the Okanagan Society for the Revival of Indian Arts and Crafts, I would advise that this is practically a branch of the similar organization in Victoria, B.C., until recently under the Presidency of Miss Ravenhill. Both of these came into being under the inspiration of Mr. Walsh, former teacher of the school at Inkameep.

As you are aware, Mr. Walsh had no professional qualifications and no great ability as a teacher but was an outstanding publicist and towards the end of his stay with us was putting on a one man platform show, including Indian dances, songs and narratives that had quite an appeal with the local uninformed intelligentsia. Eventually the increasingly unbalanced curriculum at the Indian school overtook him and some of the parents transferred their children to Cranbrook Indian Residential School, complaining that they were receiving no worthwhile education under Mr. Walsh, shortly after which he resigned to take a position in the Legion Auxiliary Services at Alberni, where he continues to interest himself in our affairs. This is probably the background of Mr. Millar's present interest in the matter. Mr. Barber's letter of September 11, 1943, will show why some of the children were transferred to Residential School.

The writer was Indian Agent for this Agency from 1930 to 1939 and is familiar with the situation and the building. The building is a simple frame 20' x 30' structure that was erected during the incumbency of Mr. Indian Agent Ball about 1922, at a cost of about $1,000.00 which it is understood was borne by the Band. The building was improved about 1932 by shingling the exterior to keep out the wind, and a garage-wood shed put up for the convenience of the teacher, this being later converted into a "studio" by Mr. Walsh.

(over)
Attached is a plan of the school on which has been noted the improvements suggested by Mr. Barber after the school has been moved to another location. While admittedly the living quarters are cramped and the building was listed for early replacement at the time new construction was ended by the war, all teachers previous to Mr. Kiernan, who took over in September 1943 and resigned during the Christmas recess, managed to make themselves very comfortable indeed. I would also point out that none of the teachers at this school had professional qualifications, apart from Mr. Kiernan who was unsatisfactory, and yet we were paying them a salary of $90.00 a month, with the small quarters complained of and fuel, at a time the locality covered by Mr. Millar's organization were paying teachers salaries somewhere in the neighbourhood of fifty dollars, without quarters. In addition to this, we were paying $10.00 a month for janitor work. No complaints were received as to conditions until Mr. Kiernan resigned and he made none to the writer when he visited the school in October 1943.

The outstanding problem at this school has been lack of water supply. A study of this problem was made by the writer in 1936 but shortly after this plans were made to induce several of the Chiefs grandchildren who were married with fair sized families to move from his house near the school and establish themselves in their own homes about a mile north of the school, when it was contemplated the school would be moved to this new community center. This, however, was complicated by a fairly large group being in residence about a mile and a half south of the school and the fact that the proposed dispersal was slow in getting started. A careful survey of school age and pre-school age children and their location is indicated before any considerable expense is incurred in moving or remodelling the present school or building a new one. Meanwhile, some essential work could be undertaken such as renewal of the floor and addition of a porch to the class room entrance.

It is evident that almost all of the furnishings are now in need of replacement. The Department stated in their letter of April 3, 1944, (file 164-11-8) in this connection that it was no longer supplying mattresses or blankets to these schools. It is possible for teachers to provide themselves with blankets, but it is considered that taking in a mattress to many of these isolated schools presents a problem that few candidates for employment would undertake during these times when competition of the white schools for these teachers is making it difficult to even hold those we have. It is felt that the Department might reconsider the decision in respect to mattresses.
The newly appointed teacher, Mr. Widdowson, is a married man with one child and without professional standing or previous experience. Whether he will be retained depends on his success during the balance of the term. If the school is to be moved or replaced, extensive repairs should not be undertaken until this is done. If it is to remain in temporary use in its present location, the porch and flooring could be attended to during the summer vacation and perhaps the addition of an extra room considered at that time. A rough estimate of the cost of these including labour would be:

April 24th, 1944.

Major D. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay,

Thank you for your letter of the 17th inst., advising this Society a teacher had been appointed to Inkameep. When in town last week, one of the Indian Mothers came up to me and told me a new teacher had arrived and they all liked him very much.

Yesterday, I went with some Members of this Society to visit the school, where we met Mr. Widdowson, his wife and young son 10 years old.

I assure you that Members of this Society and Indians on the Reserve are delighted with this appointment and we trust your Dept. will see its way clear to improve the living quarters and water supply at the School. Without wishing to intrude and with the earnest desire to be of assistance, I offer the following suggestions:

WATER SUPPLY. The well mentioned in former correspondence is no longer used by the Indians for domestic purposes. I was told by the Indians they do not consider it fit to use. The nearest good water is from a spring situated about 2,000 feet from the school. The approach is up a fairly steep ravine and it takes about fifteen minutes to fetch a bucket of water from this source.

I enquired of the Indians as to whether there was a possibility that this source of water would dry up, and was told that as long as the "nkameep Indians can remember, this source has never been known to run dry.

I suggest that a one inch pipeline be laid from the spring to the school. This would furnish an adequate supply for:

a. For the schoolchildren as washing and drinking water.
b. Domestic water supply for the teacher.
c. Irrigation water for the school and teacher's garden.

If water, even in small volume were available for the cultivation of a vegetable garden, which apart from its...
obvious utility, would make it possible to include in the school curriculum lessons in practical gardening. For these Indian children this would be a very important subject and would interest their parents as well.

Teacher's quarters.

I further suggest the possibility of re-conditioning the present schoolroom to serve as a kitchen-living room for the teacher and to build on an entirely new school-room to accommodate some 20 pupils.

If this addition were made so as to utilize the existing blank wall of the building, it would save expense.

In that case, instead of putting a new floor in the present schoolroom, I suggest cementing down a fairly good quality linoleum; not only would this be more hygienic and easy to keep clean, but it would be the least expensive in the long run.

Do you not consider that sufficient timber could be cut on the reserve to furnish the lumber for this addition to the school and to defray the expense in connection with the building and water-pipeline?

I feel sure the Indians could be prevailed upon to co-operate, especially as they are so very keen on having and keeping a Teacher in residence.

Yours sincerely,

President.

Copy to R.A. Hoey Esq.
Copy to A. Barber Esq.
Dear Mr. Hoey,

I thank you for your letter of the 13th inst., enclosing the last Branch Report and other circulars, as sent out to the Indian Agents.

Regarding the third par. of your letter; I agree that even quite modern accommodation at Inkameep would not necessarily ensure the appointment of a fully qualified teacher. At the same time a more suitable dwelling and water supply would facilitate the retention of a teacher, (even though he might be a man not specially trained for that particular type of instruction) who, if appointed, could certainly do a good deal towards instructing and guiding the young folk at Inkameep.

As you are not familiar with prevailing conditions, I do not think I can do better than to give you a copy of a letter I wrote on this subject to Commissioner McKey at Vancouver, on the 14th December last, and his reply:

"When I had the pleasure of speaking with you in September I was impressed by the keen interest you take in our Inkameep Indians. Mentioning this fact to Members of the Council, it was decided I should communicate with you in the following matter.

Whilst the Council of this Society wishes to express its gratification at the appointment of Mrs. Klaaren to the position of teacher at Inkameep Indian Day School, it feels the accommodation provided for the teacher leaves much to be desired. To say that it is primitive is to put it mildly, most of the ranchers in this district have far superior accommodation for their casual labour.

In case you are not acquainted with the facts, I would point out that the teacher's quarters consist of two - so called rooms - a bedroom approximately $8'6" \times 6'$ and a kitchen approx. $8'6" \times 8'$. In the latter there are three doors and a window. In the bedroom there is a bed with a worn-out and not very clean mattress, one makeshift table. There is no room for any other article of furniture.

The kitchen has a cookstove, a rickety table and three rough wooden shelves. One dilapidated wooden chair serves for both schoolroom and teacher's quarters. The floors are rough and have no covering and the only means for artificial lighting for both schoolroom and teacher's quarters is a small, old-fashioned single wick coal-oil lamp. The bedroom is unheated. The only heater available for heating the schoolroom and teacher's quarters is of the smallest and cheapest type that requires constant attention. For this reason it is impossible to maintain a steady temperature either in the schoolroom or teacher's quarters. The schoolroom door opens directly on to the range, consequently in zero weather the room becomes intolerably cold and I have seen snow drift right into the classroom. The same remarks apply to the teacher's kitchen.

A new floor is badly needed in the schoolroom, the present floor is not only very rough, but there are wide cracks which are full of accumulated dirt; this is definitely not hygienic."
"The most important thing in any public institution is the water supply. In the case of this Iroquois School, the source of supply is from an old hand-dug well situated some considerable distance from the school. This well has not a pump and it is open at the top; therefore it is in no way protected from dust and dirt; moreover, since the Indians also use this well to meet their domestic requirements and the water is drawn up by means of a bucket, the condition of this water supply can be left to the imagination.

I feel sure you will agree with the Council's suggestion that a comfortable living room be added to the teacher's quarters. It would not cost much to add another room and to furnish it with proper table, easy chairs, etc., and to furnish floor covering and a proper modern lamp. At the same time this is done, the schoolroom could be thoroughly reconditioned.

It must be remembered how isolated the Iroquois School is, and that the seven miles of road, or rather dirt track into Oliver, is certainly a problem, because, during the fall and winter months, it becomes a quagmire and is closed to traffic. When a teacher has to go to Oliver he has to walk. This is a further reason for asking that he be provided with some of those comforts every human being is entitled to.

The present living quarters tend to make a man feel, not only depressed, but what is worse - degraded.

The work this school has turned out has caused favourable comment in Canada, the U.S.A., and in Europe, probably more so than any other school of its kind in R.C. For this reason we would like to see the pupils and the teacher of the Iroquois Indian Day School encouraged to give of their best."

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely

Signed, Albert Miller, Pres."

To this letter, I received the following reply dated the 22nd, December, 1943.

Dear Mr. Miller,

"Acknowledging your letter of the 14th, i.e., re conditions at Osoyoos Indian Day School, I would advise you that I have asked Mr. Barber for a report on the questions raised by you.

Meanwhile, it would appear that there has been considerable neglect of this school in recent years by the teachers as, while space will not permit of more than the most simple furnishings, it was always considered reasonably comfortable and there have been no previous complaints. The two living rooms were covered with linoleum very shortly before Mr. Walsh took over, but for some reason he hasn't fit, apparently, new ones on the back boards. The table and chair may be somewhat rickety in respect to legs, but they were substantial and there were, at least, three chairs. It should impose no hardship on the teacher to reach into the classroom for a chair when necessary. With the publicity this school receives for its handicrafts it is surprising the teacher couldn't have provided himself with something better than three rough shelves. The former Agent gave the School a small set of book shelves from his own furnishings. There were two Coleman gasoline lamps in the school as well as a coal oil lamp for night use. If the floor is now dirty with dirt embedded in the cracks, it would appear to be a reflection on existing housekeeping; particularly as the teacher is away on business for janitor service for the classroom for which he may employ Indians or do the work himself. In respect to the stove, this has previously been found adequate by the teachers, one teacher keeping the windows permanently open for about a foot at the..."
bottom, covering the opening with cotton to prevent drafts.

Mr. Kiernan was given very full details of conditions at this school before he accepted the appointment and that it was situated some seven miles from Oliver. I understand that the Indians have been extremely cooperative in giving the teachers lifts to and from town. Our officials and others have gone in and out of this Reserve at all times and seasons for years and have found no great difficulty due to mud except for a few days in the spring and then only at one spot.

Mr. Kiernan was fully advised regarding the domestic water situation and that the customary source of supply was a short distance behind the school. When Mr. Inspector Coleman visited this school in October last he asked both Mr. Kiernan and the Agent to explore the possibilities of having a local man dig a well at the school if Indians could not be found for the work. If the Indians of this Reserve need this Branch to defray the cost of educating their children and find teachers at a time when they are very scarce I am sure you will agree that they themselves should be prepared to give some co-operation in such matters as this. We have schools vacant elsewhere with more commodious quarters, or where the school is close enough to a town to make teacher's quarters unnecessary, to which Mr. Kiernan could be transferred and Osayoos School closed until such time as building material and funds are available. Despite the favourable comments from outside, the fact remains that some of the parents were sending their children to Residential School on the grounds that this local school was not providing the children with the education they expected of it. In the event of its being closed the remaining children would also be transferred. Perhaps it would help here that provision has been made in the post-war program of worthwhile works for a new school with teacher's quarters to replace the existing accommodation.

Your letter does not disclose what representations Mr. Kiernan may have made to the Indian Agent in respect of these problems. Certainly none were made to the Inspector of Agencies other than a discussion of water supply, which originated with the Inspector. However, on hearing from the Indian Agent I will write you again. Yours faithfully,

signed, D.M. MacKay, Indian Comm."

To this letter I replied as follows:

January 3rd, 1944.

Dear Mr. MacKay,

"Replying to your letter of the 22nd December, I am pleased to note you have asked Mr. Barber to report on the conditions of the Osayoos Indian Day School, as raised by this Society.

For fear of prejudicing even that poor case our Indians appear to be entitled to, I will refrain from commenting on the remarks contained in the fourth paragraph of your letter pointing out other condition under which the Inkameep teacher might operate and in which event the Osayoos School could be closed,.... and in the event of its being closed the children would be transferred to Residential Schools. All I would say is that this is hardly the answer this Society expected from the Indian Commissioner for B.C. in charge of our Indian wards of the Canadian Government."
Is it not a fact that the Allies, including this Canada of ours, are fighting to uphold among other things, justice and equitable treatment to all persons and minorities, and it is the individual and minorities that go to make up Canada. The responsibility for the future good conduct and well-being of the citizen is, to a large extent dependent on the attitude of those placed in authority over him.

So one should ask oneself, how should I feel being expected to give good service as a teacher in an outlying district in circumstances such as those existing at the Inkomeep Indian Day School? Then I would ask myself - How could I like my children to be educated in surroundings and under conditions such as prevail at Inkomeep? Could I conscientiously answer that I would be satisfied especially being aware of the fact that neither the teacher or the individual child is in a position to alter the situation.

This, I believe is the test each individual in authority should put to himself when meting out something to those dependant on his sense of justice and equity.

On one point, I would make myself clear. If the teacher is expected to clean the schoolroom floor, I might mention that I have never seen it so well scrubbed or the schoolroom so tidy. But even those in authority cannot expect a teacher to take a chisel and rake out the accumulated dirt of years from cracks of nearly 1/4" separating each board. And supposing he did so, with what would he refill the cracks?

Regarding the Indians doing something for themselves; In the first place, as wards of the Government they are not expected to do things for themselves, and yet, I seem to think it was the late Indian Chief who, at his own expense built the Inkomeep Indian Day School as it now stands, because he did not wish the Indian wards to grow up illiterate. Since that time, some twelve years ago considerable progress towards more ample and more hygienic schoolrooms has been witnessed elsewhere, except at Indian Schools, especially the Indian Day School at Inkomeep where a few little native children have shown to the world the wonderful latent art and cultural background waiting to be developed so as to contribute something worthwhile to Canada and yet there seems the desire to throttle this inherent beauty through sheer neglect.

Yours sincerely,

Signed, Albert Miller, President.

I might mention that I received no further communication on this subject from Major D.M. MacKay.

For your further information I enclose copy of letter I am mailing to the Commission today, from which you will note the suggestions I make for meeting the immediate requirements of the School. In order to save time, I am sending a copy of this letter to both Major D.M. MacKay and the Indian Agent, Mr. A. Barber at Vernon.

By the way, I did not notice any of your admirable little booklets "The Beaver" at the School, were some sent there, I am sure they would prove interesting and instructive to the pupils.

Yours sincerely,

Albert Miller,
President.

Re: Inkameep Indian Day School.

May I refer to a letter dated January 17, 1944, received by you from Indian Agent Barber. In this letter Mr. Barber states:

"I have to advise that requisition was made for a new mattress, two blankets, a floor rug and an easy chair, and same was forwarded to the Department from this office on October 4, 1943, and October 15, and no word has been received."

I have made a careful study of the files and have discovered a requisition dated September 20, 1943, asking for mattresses, blankets, easy chair, etc., at the Inkameep School. This requisition was apparently sent in with another requisition for textbooks, classroom supplies, etc., and was evidently overlooked by the officials here. I have been wondering if it would be possible to persuade Indian agents, in the future, to send in requisitions for textbooks and classroom supplies and the furnishings for teachers' residences on separate forms, and perhaps in separate envelopes. I agree with you that requisitions for furnishings, repairs, etc., should be sent to your office.

I am frankly a little disturbed at the condition of a number of our Indian day and residential schools. We have had a number of resignations during the last two or three months, and unless we can do a great deal more than we are doing now to keep these buildings and teachers' residences in a good state of repair, additional resignations are likely to reach us in the immediate future.

There is -
There is, as you know, an acute shortage of teachers throughout the Dominion. Principals of normal schools and educationists generally believe that this shortage is likely to continue for perhaps a decade. If such is the case, the competition for teachers in the future is apt to be very keen and unless the salaries paid by this Branch and the accommodation provided compare favourably with the salaries paid at white schools and the accommodation available in white centres, I am afraid we are likely to secure what might be termed the dregs of the teaching profession during the decade ahead of us. We have altogether too many teachers lacking professional standing in our schools at the moment.

Would it be possible to have Indian agents report on the condition of these buildings and not wait until the president of some Indian Handicraft Society reported their condition to the Minister? It would appear that we require a new building at Inikamep, which should consist of a spacious classroom, full basement accommodation and a teacher's residence. In the meantime and until such a building is constructed, I am anxious that you should do everything humanly possible to make the living quarters at this school reasonably comfortable.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. MacKay,

I have been doubtful as to the form into which I should throw the remarks which I have to make on the improvement of Indian education; but have finally decided to write them in the form of a letter, which you can have transcribed in any way which you may wish if they are to be transmitted to Ottawa.

The first point which I should like to make is that, just as in white education the city school with a class room for each grade may be taken as normal, in Indian education, the small school with several or all grades at work in one room under one teacher must be taken as normal. This means that, although one wishes to depend as little as possible upon the textbook, there must be long periods of time when the teacher is occupied with other grades, in which the pupil must of necessity be left largely to textbook or work-book; blackboard work for any one grade is in the same way only possible for a small part of the total school time.

Again, I must criticise the present policy of the Branch to depend upon the Provincial textbooks. In the present state of Indian education there is far more in common between the needs of the Indians in the several provinces than there is between those of Indians and whites within the same province. Leaving out of the question differences of psychology between peoples of different colour, there remain two factors of far-reaching importance:

First, very few Indian children have any intellectual background, such as most white children have; second, English is a foreign language, and it is an inefficient proceeding to use the same textbooks as are used for children to whom English is their mother-tongue.

The teaching of arithmetic requires special textbooks, with the directions to the pupil in very much simplified language. One notices in present-day arithmetic texts an unfortunate tendency to use complicated and difficult words in place of simple and readily understood ones. That is unfortunate in any case, with Indians doubly so. There are many books available in which the distribution of arithmetical facts is good enough, but need rewriting as to the English used to convey the facts, to bring it down at least two grades in its comprehensibility.

Apart from Arithmetic, it is my view that the whole of the necessary subjects for the first three grades—which are by far the most important—could and should be embodied in a single course roughly corresponding to Reading. All that need be taught in the way of Social Studies, and the elements of the scientific knowledge...
of things, could be included in a judicious choice of pieces for inclusion in the readers. That will of course mean that the readers will have to be larger than at present. The plan of Macmillan's New Work-Play Books is as good as any that can be devised; but the bulk requires increasing, and the reading matter adapted to the needs of the Indians.... This, by the way, does not mean that they should be about Indians, or be interlarded with "Indian" words derived from the languages of all but or quite extinct tribes of the East; but that they shall be about topics to a large extent those that appeal to Indians, such as animals and riding; a considerable proportion of the authentic fairy tales of the near East (which possess these interests, would seem to be indicated). In fact, for the real education of the children, the environment should be rather that of which we wish to inform the children, and not their own, with all that it implies of resistance to civilised ways. The illustrations also, should attain to a high artistic level (here again the Work-Play Books may be referred to approvingly) as Indian children are apt to use the illustrations in their readers as artistic raw materials; it would also be as well that the technique of the drawings should be such as to help in this way (that is to say, not involving the use of light lines and washes) and that the range of subjects should include a great quantity in which bathing scenes are depicted, or some related subject which would provide the excuse for giving the children plenty of unconscious instruction in the anatomy of the human body. (When teaching I have suffered considerable discomfort from the ignorance of the children in this matter.)

I would further suggest that the use of these readers should be made compulsory in all Indian schools; and that religious interests should be represented by the permission and encouragement of religious bodies to provide supplementary readers of considerable bulk (if desired), planned to fit in with the general scheme of the main readers. The provincial interests could also be represented by a further series of locally provided supplementary readers.

And I would in addition advocate the provision, at each grade level, of "home readers" which would be given to the children to take home with them, which might lead to a gradual raising of the level of the homes themselves. Here also, religious and provincial supplementaries would be invited.

In all the readers I would suggest that uniform system of lettering be insisted upon, such as I have written out upon the enclosed sheet. As it is to be presumed that the readers for the first three grades would be reproduced photographically, there
would not be the slightest difficulty in setting the words done for reproduction along with the drawings. It is further to be desired that at the first level only those capital letters should be used whose forms are identical with those of the small letters, other capitals, and also forms of some of the small letters which in letterpress are different from those in the attached alphabet being introduced gradually.... The merit of the attached alphabet lies in the fact that the proportions of the letters are given a definite rationale, which appeals to the logical Indian mind. Thus the O is an exact circle, the C is derived from it by drawing the circumscribed square and its diagonals; a good many letters are based upon it, and it is taken as the measure for the width of most of the other letters.

I was myself surprised at the speed with which the children at Inkaneep, who had never before been introduced to a properly constructed alphabet, took to this one and marvellously increased the neatness of their work at all grades.... For this can well be taught as a preliminary to writing, which in my opinion should not be expected of Indians too soon.... It would be a great advantage to have properly ruled paper for practicing lettering, and reducing the size with the increasing age of the pupil, such as is unfortunately not done at all in Canada. The cost would be trifling.

To turn to practical life, I would like to see the Indian customs used as a basis for the teaching of cleanliness. There is no reason why the Indians should not be told - as it is the truth - that their own sweat-house method of keeping clean is superior to our European methods. But that for European clothes they should turn to European methods. I would advocate the adoption of uniforms which, as Government property, the Government could insist upon being kept clean, probably by a laundry class of the dirtiest snirt-and-shorts for the boys and short frocks for the girls, with not too much extra piled on for the winter, would be in addition conducive to health.

I am aware that much of this would involve the outlay of considerable amounts of money. But in the rehabilitation schemes which are now rife, I understand that money is going to be spent anyhow, and I consider that some such scheme as I have outlined (and as to any part of which I could of course supply further details) would be very productive or good.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Re: Inkameep Indian Day School

I enclose herewith results of a survey recently made by Mr. Superintendent Sampson in connection with the above-mentioned school. It will be noted that there are sufficient pupils to justify the operation of a one-room school on the Inkameep Reserve. The very unsatisfactory operation of this school during the last four or five years is undoubtedly due to our inability to secure and retain a competent teacher. It is felt that the unsatisfactory living conditions at the school and the acute shortage of qualified Catholic teachers are the main factors in our difficulty in securing suitable teachers and it is hoped that it will be possible to construct a new school at Inkameep during the current fiscal year.

Mr. Davey recently visited this reserve with Mr. Sampson and came to the conclusion that the existing site is the most suitable location for a new school.

March 14th, 1950.

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Attention of Mr. R.F. Davey, Inspector of Indian Schools

Re: Inkameep Day School

Further to our recent discussion about this school, the following information is submitted:

(a) There are currently 12 children available for attendance at this school.

(b) The 6 children in attendance at Omak School could attend at Inkameep if the school is opened. They were sent to Omak early in the term when it was thought the school was not going to operate.

(c) There are four children at Kamloops Residential School who apparently have no reason for not attending the Inkameep School, as there are other children in the family who are living at home and the family circumstances are more or less normal.

(d) There are 13 preschool children and 13 children who will be discharged during the next six years, so attendance will apparently remain about the same.

Owing to the distance from the public schools in Oliver and the difficult road over which children would have to travel, it does not seem practical to entertain the idea of
transporting the children from the Reserve into the Oliver schools, although the School Board has signified their willingness to accept these children.

The present school building at Inkameep is inadequate for our purposes, both as to living quarters and classroom. The original construction was very poor, there having been no insulation applied, with the result the school is hot in the summer and cold in the winter; both the school and the living quarters are far too small; the lighting is very poor, there being insufficient window area; the water system is impractical in its present state owing to improper installation.

Owing to the impossibility of carrying out practical improvements to the existing building, it is strongly recommended that a new building, including living quarters and inside sanitation be constructed, and that a new water system be installed which will provide adequate storage and proper insulation of the pipes from freezing.

With regard to the water supply, the Indians inform me that spring from which the school has been drawing water is open all year round and that the water is of good quality.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Superintendent,
