Dear Tony:

I am just leaving for Western Canada and will not return until Christmas. I hope to look in on the Inkamoose School and will endeavour to contact some of your former pupils. I will bring back what news I can, of their progress.

You will be interested to know that we are now building a new school after having overcome many difficulties.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Dear Bernard:

Thank you so much for your note. I was glad to know that you'll soon be in your new house, and thus escape moving before the coming of the hot weather. It is only now that we are getting warm weather in these parts. From the top of the Mount, I've been watching throughout the last week, the trees assuming their green clothes. It was a marvelous experience to watch the change of colouring from day to day. I'm fascinated by the Mount, because six minutes' walk takes me away from the rush of the city and I'm in peaceful surroundings as in the Okanagan.

Since I last wrote to you, I've done much writing. My three-act play on St. Noel Chabanel, 'Triumphant Failure,' is now ready for printing. I've just received a letter from the head of Dramatics Dept at Penn State College, (We were at Band together for a couple of years.) He states,

"Sorry to have kept the enclosed manuscript so long, I have read it with great interest but have been hoping to get a little more time to write you concerning it. I am truly hardly competent to judge it. It does not follow the usual pattern of a play—it is episodic with a broad sweep—almost a movie scenario. But I believe it will be very moving if performed well. I am wondering whether your Catholic patrons will like the bitter note at the ending. Despite any faults the whole consent has a kind of magnificence about it. And I wish you very much luck with it."

With regards to the bitter ending, it brings out the point that for the time being the Church is crushed, but of course we know that She returns. Non-Caths find it very hard to accept failure.

I've also completed a short story, an hour-long radio play, 'Symphony of the Plains,' and am now at the tail end of a one-act. It is about very serious matters, but is turning into a comedy. There is a wonderful old gal, Nora Connolly, who has taken the bit in her teeth and is running away with the show, so I'm having quite a time between chuckles, trying to keep her in her place.

Last Friday night I did a show for the Montreal Branch of Fed of Can Artists. There were a wonderful audience, but as they have no funds, there was no remuneration in cash. Wasn't there some gal named Marie Antoinette who stated, when she heard people were starving and bread was called giving them oats? Well, I also need bread, but in place of cake, got a beautiful picture by an artist of Montreal who made many studies of the Caughnawaga Indians. I also got a script accepted by the International Service of the CBC, but it is going to be nip and tuck whether I can scrape up enough cash to keep me going through June.

On July 2nd I became manager for the Montreal Summer Theatre at Loyola College. I'm also to have charge of experiment children's productions. As they are starting from scratch, I'll just be getting a pittance. But it will bring me in touch with people of influence with the Cath Schools Commission, and may
lead to some part-time work with Eng Cath schools. And who knows
is this is successful, there may be an opportunity of part time
work teaching Indian art and drama at Caughnawaga.

All my friends and associates have run into some kind
of trouble or other, either personal, family or business, so our
projects have had to be postponed.

I hope that Betty, the youngsters and yourself
are all well, and that the number of headaches in the Department
are diminishing.

I see little likelihood of visiting Ottawa, because
its a case of cents these days, not dollars.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa, February 12, 1918.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, requesting that a cheque be forwarded for the salary of Miss Christine McLeod, teacher of the Osceola Indian Day School, for her services for the three months ending November 30th, last.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $125.00 is being sent you under separate cover for Miss McLeod, being an advance on her salary for the period she taught this school from September 10th to December 31st, last.

A supply of blank quarterly day school return forms is enclosed herewith and you will be good enough to instruct Miss McLeod to prepare returns showing the attendance and days taught for the periods ending September 30th and December 31st and forward them to you for transmission to the Department. I may say that salaries are only paid upon receipt of the quarterly returns of attendance. The quarters end on the 30th of September, 31st of December, 31st of March and 30th of June, respectively, and in preparing her returns she should comply with these periods. She should prepare a return promptly at the end of each quarter and forward it through your office. You will be good enough to see that she prepares returns and forwards them immediately for the December quarter last in order that the balance of salary due for that period can be paid.

Your obedient servant

J. Robt. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sumnerland, B. C.

Unfortunately the Osoyoos Indian Day School was closed during the term as we were unable to secure the services of a teacher, but hope to remedy this after the summer vacation.

F. J. C. Ball,
Agt.
Ottawa, August 15th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing copy of an application which you received from Miss Mary Wadel for the position as teacher of the Osayoos Indian Day School, and stating the qualifications which she possesses.

In reply I beg to say that, if the Roman Catholic Church authorities, under whose auspices this school is conducted, approve of the appointment of this girl, the Department will consent to her appointment, temporarily, with salary at rate of $75 per teaching month, her retention in the position, however, to depend upon the success which she meets in the work.

We are informing Mr. Agent Ball of the application of Miss Wadel, and of the necessity of obtaining the approval of the Church authorities for her appointment. Please take this matter up with the Church authorities, and inform the Department and Mr. Agent Ball as to whether they approve of the appointment of Miss Wadel, and, if so, if you have arranged with her to begin duties on September 1st, next.

Your obedient servant,

R. H. Cairns, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Schools,
Room 602, Holsten Bldg.,
Vancouver, B.C.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, March 31st, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, informing the Department that, owing to a case of chicken pox or smallpox having occurred at the Osoyoos Indian Day School, the school has been closed on the advice of the Medical Officer. We note that the Reserve has been quarantined and that all who were not previously vaccinated in recent years are being vaccinated. It is hoped that no further cases will develop and that it will be possible to reopen the school at an early date. I shall be pleased to hear later regarding this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, November 25th, 1927.

Madam:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in which you advise that you have not yet received your cheque for the month of September last. On looking up this matter, I find that, while your cheque is usually sent to Mr. F.J. Ball, Indian Agent, Vernon, B.C., it was, in error, forwarded addressed to yourself at Vernon. The cheque left here on October 17th and, no doubt, is still lying at the post office at Vernon. Please write the postmaster at that point and ascertain if it is there. If not, you should advise me.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sept 16-19

Dear Mr. Ball,

Received your letter and your request of explaining why I have resigned so sudden as teacher of the Sekameep River School.

I am sure that you have been Indian Agent long enough to know how hard it is to deal with the Indians when they are anger at you, and also that the word of the priests is law to them.

This where my trouble started with the Sekameep Indians when I married outside of the Catholic Church. I heard before I reached the Reserve that I was going to be put out of my position if necessary by force. I was ordered out of one house in fact for the same reason. I want you to know that I am married by law and have my papers to show for same.

Under these circumstances I am sure you will find it in your heart and also Mr. McPhail to forgive me. I didn't mean
to be harsh to you nor the office, but I just wanted to "beat" the Indians in their intentions & making an object of daughter of me among themselves and the white-people. I have never complained nor complained what I had to bear in the last two years trying to educate my people.

At the time I saw you at Cowell I fully intended returning to work, or else I would have told you differently. It was at the latter part of August when I found out on my way to Sukamoo what the Indians thought of my marriage, which they claimed we not been married at all.

Many of the members would not speak to me when I reached the Reserve. I spoke to Chief Peter and told him that I was giving up my work, and went on to Pembina and call up Mr. and Mrs. McGrady's office which I failed to find either one of you there.

Thanking you for your past kindness and interest in me. Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Christina M. Miller

I beg to enclose herewith the resignation of Christine McLeod teacher of the Osoyoos Day School as requested in your letter of the 11th ult. This is dated September 16th but has only reached the office today.

I have recently learned that Christina McLeod was married and divorced several years ago and has now re-married. The Superintendent of the Colville (Washington) Indian Reservation has known her 20 years and she has always borne an exemplary character. Since her re-marriage the Indians have objected to her returning as teacher though they have doubtless been influenced by the priest, Father Bellot, who might also use his influence to prevent so many Indians living together without being married at all either by law or by the priest, and I have called this state of things to his notice several times. He is strongly opposed to the Osoyoos or any other day school, as he plans to start an Industrial school at Penticton where all the Reserves shall send their children and their maintenance to be paid for by the Department. This is quite impracticable as the majority of the Indians will not allow their children to leave the reserve and the expense to the Department would be out of proportion to the education given.

I have continually worked for more
schools on the Reserves and always meet with stubborn opposition from the older members of the Bands and there is no doubt that this opposition is instructed and not natural.

Father Bellot was formerly in the Stuart Lake Agency B.C.

I am making every effort to secure the services of another teacher for Ocoyoona Indian Day School and will report when successful.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 27th ult., regarding repairs to the school at Inkameep, I beg to advise that the building used as a school is really the priest's house close to the church and is the property of the Band. It is a 12 x 15 room and the priest never uses it. The school building proper is a much larger building near by, but for several reasons has not been used. The foundations have rotted and it is in a dilapidated condition, but the real reason is that it is too close to the graveyard, some of the graves being within a few feet of the wall and it was claimed that the children are nervous and afraid to enter the building.

The priest's house, now used as the school, requires new flooring and the ceiling repaired, and the whole work would need lumber to the value of $75.00 to make it comfortable for winter. This lumber could be obtained from the Provincial Irrigation Works within five miles of the school and the Indians promise to haul it and repair the building without further expense.

Next year there will be a large quantity of lumber available when the big ditch is completed and I would suggest that the present building be repaired to make it habitable for the coming winter, but advantage taken of the opportunity to
build a rather larger and better school building next year when the irrigation lumber becomes available.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Pallet,

Referring to the attached letter from Mr. Agent Ball, I wish to state that the Osoyoos Band have had a school on and off for the past two years. There are roughly ten children of school age. The school was closed the end of June, last, as we were unable to secure a teacher - lack of boarding accommodation was the chief reason for our failure.

There is a very old school building on the Reserve which is not suitable for any purpose. Of late, school has been held in the priest's house, which was given for the purpose. I am of the opinion that $500 or $400 will put this building in good shape as a school house, but, in addition, we will have to provide a small teacher's residence, if school activities are to be continued.

R.F.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir —

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant and in reply would say that the Priest's house on the Osoyoos Reserve is constructed of hewn logs and on account of its age is quite unfit to be used for any purpose whatever. Permission was granted by the Department last year to expend $75.00 on it to fix it up, but it was found that nothing could be done on account of the unstable condition, and the amount was not applied for.

The members of the Osoyoos Band are widely scattered at present. Not more than eight children of school age reside in the vicinity of the settlement so that it is not desirable to build a substantial residence and school on this Reserve. I would suggest however that a building quite good enough for a combined school and residence could be erected locally for about $500.00. This would be a plain frame building large enough for ten or twelve pupils and two rooms for a teacher. On account of the remoteness of this Reserve from white settlements, I do not think we shall ever be able to obtain a white teacher and it would not be advisable to put up any substantial building where the school population is not likely to increase but rather diminish. The proposed new school at Penticton will probably be large enough to accommodate the Osoyoos children, although the Osoyoos Band have not taken kindly to the idea so far. In any event the temporary school located in the Priest's house at Penticton is filled so that no effort has been made to have the Osoyoos children brought over to Penticton. I believe the best plan will be to hold over the building of any school at Osoyoos until after the Penticton School is completed. It may be that when they see a substantial
school building on the Penticton Reserve the parents of the few who have attended at Osoyoos in the past will be willing to bring their children over.

I have just received a wire from the Chief's son, at Osoyoos, which reads as follows:-

"We have teacher, she is starting next week".

I have written for full particulars about this teacher and have asked her to make an application to the Department for the position as the information contained in the telegram was very meagre. The teachers who have taught school on the Osoyoos Reserve so far have been half-breeds who lived with the Indians and where such teachers are available and satisfactory, this is the best arrangement and, I believe that this new teacher will also prove to be a half-breed. Previous teachers have either lived in one of the Indian houses or put up a frame with tent roof and have been quite satisfied, although a white teacher, of course, would not live under these conditions throughout the year.

I do not know what building the Osoyoos Band intend to use in future as a temporary school. The last time I visited the Reserve the Chief's son said he might use a room in his house as the only children attending school at present were his family and near relatives.

I hope the new proposed school at Penticton will be commenced as early as possible.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, January 3, 1923.

Sir:-

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 19th ultimo, enclosing a cheque for $350 - an amount which was requested some months ago by the Osayoos Band in order to paint their church. I have noted that it will be impossible to use this money for the purpose intended until a later date.

With reference to the suggestion that a portion of the band funds be used to build a small house, the Department is of the opinion that the old priest's home, which was given for the purpose, might be put in good condition for a small sum and that, if any building activity is undertaken, it should be a residence. You will remember that we could not open school this last fall, because there was no residence for a teacher.

Will you make a recommendation to the Department, indicating whether or not a new school at Penticton will cater to the educational needs of the children of the Osayoos Band. If not, and if there are sufficient children to warrant the expense, consideration will be given to taking some of the Osayoos Band funds - augmented, perhaps, by parliamentary appropriation - for the erection of a teacher's residence and, if necessary, a new school house.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy Secretary.

Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 30th ultimo, relative to the provision of a small school house and residence at the Osceola Indian Day School. The Deputy Superintendent General has authorized the erection of a building, as indicated by the rough sketch which you enclosed. You may make arrangements with Mr. H. Parsons, the local contractor, to erect a plain, substantial building to be used for the purposes of a classroom and a teacher's residence. Mr. Parsons' rough sketch called for a building 26 ft. by 14 ft. The Department Architect suggests dimensions of 30 ft. by 16 ft., so that the living accommodation will be more adequate.

Please make arrangements with the contractor to have the building erected, under your supervision, on a proven cost plus ten per cent basis. All accounts will have to be certified by yourself, and proper time sheets should be kept for the labour employed. As a guide, the Department suggests to you and to Mr. Parsons that the total cost be between $550 and $900. The cost of the building will be charged to the interest at the credit of the Band.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

I beg to refer to your letter of December 12th last authorizing the erection of the Osayoos Indian Day School with two rooms as a residence.

This work has been very satisfactorily completed along the lines suggested by the Department's architect of a building 30' x 16'. The work was handled by Mr. Henry Parsons and one assistant and time sheets for the labour are attached. I also enclose all shipping bills and itemized accounts for inspection. The building is a very substantial building on concrete piles and has met with the approval of the chief of the Band.

As will be seen by the statements, the total cost is $947.50. I tried to have the cost kept below $900.00 and would have done so except for the painting, the expense of which was overlooked in figuring out the cost of the building with Mr. Parsons.

Without extra expense, I have had this account checked over by an architect friend and he states that the prices are as charged on work in Penticton and vicinity. Labour is charged at 70¢ an hour both by Mr. Parsons and his assistant. This also is the wage paid at this point.

The work has been carefully and conscientiously performed by Mr. Parsons, and it is regretted

Sir,

"I have received from Miss Mary Wadell a list of articles needed in connection with the teacher's residence. In this list there is an application for a pair of blankets and a pair of sheets. I do not feel that I would be justified in recommending the purchase of these.

Should there be a change of teachers blankets and sheets would be very easily lost sight of, so that I think it would be better for the teacher to own her own blankets and sheets.

I am enclosing the requisition for School Material and would suggest that you make any changes therein that you may deem necessary, and forward it to the Department."

Sir,— Re Painting Osoyoos Day School File 164-11-5.

Replying to your letter of June 27th, I beg to advise that I have inspected the Indian Day School on Osoyoos Indian Reserve No.1 and by measurement find that this building is 18'5" x 30' x 10', and, in my opinion, of very poor construction, being little more than a rather badly built shack.

The outside appears to be common siding nailed direct to the studding and the inside three-ply cottonwood veneer applied direct to studding. The outside siding has shrunk rather badly and, in places, it is possible to insert the fingers. The veneer lining had been put on so badly that it forms very poor protection and the result is that the high winds prevalent in this district blow clean through the school.

In view of this condition, I would recommend that the outside be covered with tar paper, and shingled on top of the siding, which if properly done would give a weatherproof building. The total cost of this work, with one coat of shingle stain to walls and roof, should not exceed $200.00 with an additional $25.00 for windows and doors. I would also strongly recommend interior re-decoration at a cost not to exceed $75.00, the inside being unpainted except the strips holding veneer panels and the whole being in a very dingy condition.

For a paint job alone, I estimate the cost not to exceed $225.00 for outside work, and $75.00 for interior, or a total of $300.00 in all; but apart from the roof, I do not consider the outside worth the expenditure in its present condition, other than from a decorative viewpoint; particularly, as there would be very little difference in the comparative costs. I would further suggest that paint and material be purchased by the Department and not by the individual performing the work, ensuring first-class material. As the Indians of this reserve are rather above the average in intelligence, and they have done excellent paint work on their own houses, I believe we would secure a perfectly satisfactory job to have one of them do the work under the supervision of the teacher, Mr. Grist, and, if this was done, we would eliminate a daily taxi charge for a sixteen mile return trip.
from the nearest town, which would run quite high and would, of course, be charged to the job. I can personally undertake to see that the work is completed in a good shape.

This school also requires a woodshed, there being no outbuilding whatever, apart from latrines. The cost of this will not exceed $100.00, if authorized.

This school has been giving me considerable cause for thought on account of low attendance and high costs per pupil, and I have advised the Indians of this Reserve that every child of school age and within reasonable distance of the school must attend. I do not wish to recommend closing the school for the reason that the majority of the Indians are very keen on keeping it open, this school being the first in this agency, and, I understand, originally opened by the Indians themselves at their own expense, but with the present average attendance, it appears to me that it would be better to run the school for three days per week, and utilize the services of the teacher in the Similkameen for part time, as they have been calling for a school there for the past two or three years.

I am reporting fully on this matter in a separate letter, and would appreciate your instructions in regard to both subjects. I have deferred the painting of Osoyoos School until such time as Mr. Grist returned, in order that we would have a check on the work.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(James Coleman)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Barry, in a report on his recent inspection of the Osoyoos Indian Day School, has recommended that a new stove be supplied previous to the opening of the school next fall. The Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of a new stove for the school and the linoleum required for the two rooms in the teacher's residence. You should forward an account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the stove after the purchase has been made next summer.

Sir:

I enclose herewith Voucher No.4026 for $5.04, being automobile expenses incurred by Mr.F.Grist teacher of the Indian Day School at Osoyoos I.R.No.1, during the recent visit of Mr.Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.

On March 27th I requested Mr.Barry to investigate the question of a school on Lower Similkameen Indian Reserves No.7 & 8, and arranged to take him over there, but unfortunately was unable to do so by reason of the visit of Miss Craig, Western Supervisor of the V.O.N. on the same date, and I was very anxious that she should include the nurse at Keremeos in her inspection, and as there was no direct way for her to reach that point from Oliver, asked Mr.Grist to take Mr.Barry to the Similkameen, and I took Miss Craig to Keremeos. Mr.Grist's return trip amounted to over 140 miles.

It was also necessary for Mr.Grist to make an emergency trip from the Reserve to Penticton, a return trip of over 70 miles, on the 24th of March with an Indian girl requiring medical treatment.

Sir,

Sir:

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. S. PRAGNELL,
dated May 10, 1935. (P.O. Box 752, Kamloops, B.C.)

Original on 77-16

INKANEEL DAY SCHOOL: I found everything very satisfactory under Mr. Walsh at this day school. There were ten in class on the date of my visit, out of eleven on the roll. The reading and writing of all the children was quite good. They were sending an exhibit of handicraft made by the pupils to an exhibition of handicraft held in Vernon, and I understood that this exhibit was very favourably commented on. Part of it was pottery work. This school has also exchanged handicraft with a school in Czecho Slovakia.

One small improvement that should be done at this day school is to pipe the water from its source, a spring a little way up the hill back of the school, down to the school building. This is necessary from the health point of view, instead of the children and the teacher having to take their water out of the creek flowing near the school, which the cattle also use. However, as the teacher lives at the day school, it would be a great convenience to him, which should receive consideration. In addition I might say that this spring runs all the time, but the creek itself dries up about the beginning of July, and it means quite a climb up hill to get water after the creek has stopped running.
Sir:

Re: Your File No.164-11-5

Replying to your letter of the 5th instant regarding Mr. Inspector Fragill's report regarding water for Osopos Day School, I would advise that I provided for an expenditure of $385.00 in my 1935-6 Estimates for this purpose.

Unfortunately, the spring is not so close to the school as would be gathered from the Inspector's report; as it is about a quarter of a mile up a rocky gulch where excavation would be difficult. The water supply amounts to only a mere trickle during the summer months, but the school is closed during that period. The only other supply is about a mile distant and difficult to bring to the school. Sinking a well would be problematical, owing to rock formation, an Indian well nearby being dry most of the year.

It might be possible to curtail the expenditure somewhat and the cost would be kept as low as possible.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(James Coleman)
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 18, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the water supply for the Osceola Indian Day School and giving an estimate of the cost of installing a pipeline from a spring located about one quarter mile from the school.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will have no funds this year to cover the cost of having this work carried out. A note has been made to provide the expenditure - approximately $385.00 - in our Estimates for the next fiscal year. Before incurring any expenditure, however, the Department would require to be definitely assured that there would be an ample supply of water obtained from the spring and also that the pipe could be installed in a manner to prevent freezing in winter. It is noted that the result from the sinking of a well would be problematical, owing to rock formation. You might furnish full information with your estimates for the next fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
